60 MCQ

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5120a026dbf87010fe4b322af4961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5920a026dbf87010fe4b322af4961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ed3e4e6dbf87010fe4b322af496194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"CASA RPLA","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"40","description":"

A federally mandated professional accreditation examination conducted by the aviation regulator (no UNSW resources required), a pass in which is required to achieve the Recreational Pilot Licence.

https://www.casa.gov.au/standard-page/rpl-and-ppl-exams

Feedback is immediate via Knowledge Deficiency Report issued by the regulator in accordance with legislation.

This course is taught in an interactive context, developing library research skills and written, oral and presentation communication skills.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6d0ba62bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Presentation - Video","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Interview in video format - 15%

Due Date – Last week of course 

Length – 7-8 Minutes (including approx. 2 minutes question time)

Task– Individuals will be allocated groups of between 5 and 7 members. Each group will be allocated a topic and the task is to create a short interview with experts on the topic. There will be one interviewer, and the remainder of the students are experts and will be asked a series of questions about the topic (i.e. interviewees). The objective of the interview is to provide a comprehensive overview of the topic in a professional and informative manner. You are free to set the scene of the interview. In other words, you may elect to commence the interview with the backdrop of an accident, change in legislation, protest, etc. 

You should aim to include:

  • background information, 
  • definition/s, 
  • significance of the issue/s in present day aviation, 
  • link to research, and
  • future implication/direction.

Groups must be ready to present their video (interview) at the start of class during in the final week. The video must last for five minutes. After the video, class members will have an opportunity to ask questions. All group members must both feature in the video as well as be present for the presentation and question time. Failure to feature in the video and/or be present for the presentation will automatically result in the absent student/s receiving a zero mark for the assessment. Finally, students are to provide a copy of the minutes from each meeting. Students will be assessed on both the video (see presentation marking guide) and the minutes. Feedback provided on marking criteria including comments and mark out of 10. Feedback provided within one week of due date.

This exam is held during the University examination period and is designed to test the student's knowledge of all topics covered in AVIA1321 throughout the term. The exam format consists of multiple choice questions and two essays. The final exam is 2 hours duration with 10 mins reading time, and constitutes 45% of the final grade. Feedback is not provided as it is an externally managed final exam, but the student will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper if they wish.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"510ba62bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5d0ba62bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"990ba62bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d0ba62bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Written","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Aim – The aim of this assessment, from an academic perspective is twofold. 

  1. Group Performance. This assessment is designed to build and or enhance team skills, such as: management skills, delegation skills, communication skills, and leadership skills. 
  2. Area/topic knowledge. This assessment is designed to foster in the development of knowledge in an aviation specific area. 

In pursuit of these two aims, this assessment contains a number of milestones which must be met by students. The two obvious milestones are: the written submission and the video presentation (interview with experts on a particular topic). In addition to these two milestones, students are expected to keep minutes of every meeting (ideally secretary take notes and distribute to all team members; see How to Take Minutesreading for more information). These minutes, must include although not limited to:

  1. When and where the meeting took place,
  2. Who was present and absent,
  3. The reason for the meeting,
  4. What was discussed, decided and who is responsible for agreed action/s,
  5. Textbook references if appropriate,
  6. The date of the next meeting,
  7. When the meeting closed, and
  8. Signatures of all present to indicate accuracy and agreement to the minutes. 

Students will be assessed on both of these milestones. In week 12 students will present their video along with minutes from each meeting in hard copy (handed to lecturer). As highlighted above, the minutes should include information pertaining to the above seven points (at a minimum). 

 

 

 

Steps Required to Successfully Pass Assessment 

Step 1: Complete Written Submission (15%)

Step 2: Complete Presentation (15%)

Step 3: Provide evidence of Team Work in the form of Minutes from each meeting

Group Written Submission – 15%

Due Date – TBA

Length– 1,000 words (not including references)

Format– Hard Copy to Course Coordinator – Dr Brett Molesworth with signed cover sheet.

Based on the groups allocated for the interview video presentation, students are required in addition to the interview recording submit a written summary of the topic/area under investigation. It is expected that the written submission contains information about the topic/area under investigation including:

  • background information, 
  • definition/s, 
  • explanation of topic/area,
  • significance of the issue/s in present day aviation, 
  • link to research, and
  • future implication/direction.

The contents of this submission should not be a summary of your interview, but a summary of the topic/area under investigation/examination. As this is an academic piece of writing, you are expected to include citations in text as well as a reference list. The reference list is notincluded in the word count. You also need to format your submission, including references as per the American Psychology Association (APA) style guide. Importantly, internet references including Wikipedia are notacademic sources. Hence, I expect your reference list to contain only books or journal papers. Finally, peer evaluation forms can be found under the assessment tab. If no peer evaluation forms are submitted (handed in with assignment or at end of presentation), it will be assumed that all students contributed equally to the two components (group presentation and written submission) of the group assessment.

Feedback will be provided within two week of submissin and consist of a detailed set of comments on submission in addition to a mark out of 10.

Hence, a progress test will be conducted during week TBA. The test will take the form of multiple-choice questions. All material up until week TBA will be examined, including material presented in lectures, tutorials and required readings. 

Feedback. Feedback will be provided in the form of the correct answer and topic under examination. Feedback will be provided within two weeks of the assessment submission.

contentlets.description: The course provides a foundation for the range of courses provided in the BAv, and includes a general description of the aviation industry. Topics are chosen from the main organisations and the regulatory environment: introductory aviation economics and management practices for airlines and airports; basic aeronautical knowledge including aircraft performance, operation and  navigation; international and organisational cultures; human factors; aviation safety. This course is taught in an interactive context, developing library research skills and written, oral and presentation communication skills.

Nonetheless, with the correct application of knowledge, planning and design, systems can be designed with the human in mind to facilitate in human performance. This course examines human behaviour from a theoretical perspective, with the intent to optimise the relationship between humans and their environment. With the focus primarily on the individual, this course examines basic human cognition, including perception, memory, information processing, and decision-making. These principles are then applied to the aviation industry to understand the design of systems (i.e., flight deck, consoles, aircraft, etc) for human use.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"175d56a3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619fd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Aim – The aim of this assessment, from an academic perspective is threefold. 

  1. Group Performance. This assessment is designed to build and or enhance team skills, such as: management skills, delegation skills, communication skills, and leadership skills. 
  2. Area/topic knowledge. This assessment is designed to foster in the development of knowledge in an aviation specific area. 
  3. Communication skills. Develop communication skills to enable the succinct delivery of key and pertinent information.

In pursuit of this, the assessment contains a number of milestones which must be met by students. The obvious milestone is the video presentation. In addition, students are expected to keep minutes of every meeting (ideally secretary take notes and distribute to all team members). These minutes, must include, although not limited to:

  1. Meeting date,
  2. Note attendees,
  3. Note roles assigned to team members,
  4. Note tasks assigned to team members,
  5. Document when assigned tasks are due,
  6. Document completion of assigned tasks, and
  7. Document reasons why assigned tasks were not completed, etc.

Students will be assessed on all milestones. In week 10 students will present their video along with minutes from each meeting in hard copy (hand to lecturer). As highlighted above, the minutes should include information pertaining to the above seven points (at a minimum). 

 

Steps Required to Successfully Pass Assessment 

Step 1: Complete Movie Presentation

Step 2: Provide evidence of Team Work in the form of Minutes from each meeting

Overview 

Students are required to work in groups of approximately 6 people and create a five-minute movie focusing on a poorly designed physical object within the field of aviation. The movie must be played during class in Week 10. The lecturer has allocated two minutes following the movie for questions. 

Detail

Following the census date in Week TBA, students will be allocated to a group with approximately 6 members. The groups must work cohesively to create a five-minute movie to be played during class in Week 10. 

The content of the movie will be based on a physical object, within the field of aviation, which is not designed for intuitive use. 

Examples of such objects can be sourced from week 1 lecture notes and include doors, signs, equipment, aircraft controls, etc. 

Students are not permitted to select a mobile telephone as the object for this assignment. In completing this assignment, it is expected that the groups cover at least the following as a minimum:

  • Clearly explain the item under examination, 
  • Its purpose, 
  • The perceived flaw or limitation, 
  • How it is not user-friendly, 
  • The potential problems from interacting with the item, and
  • How it could be modified or improved (based on evidence – research). 

Groups must be ready to present their movie at the start of class during Week 10. The movie must last for no longer than five minutes (maximum). All group members must bothfeature in the movie as well as be present for the presentation and question time. 

NB: If the presentation is not associated with an object within aviation and/or a group member or members are not present in both the movie and when it is presented in Week 10, these members will receive a mark of 0 (zero).

Feedback. Student will be provided feedback about their presentation in the form of a written response, including a mark out of 10. This will be sent via email no later than one week following the presentation.

This exam is held during the University examination period and is designed to test the student's knowledge of all topics covered in AVIA1401 throughout the term. The exam format consists of multiple choice questions and two essays. The final exam is 2 hours duration with 10 mins reading time, and constitutes 45% of the final grade. Feedback is not provided as it is an externally managed final exam, but the student will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper if they wish.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"535d56a3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8b5d56a3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c75d56a3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f25d56a3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay - Individual Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment 1: Essay (total mark 30% - 20% essay + 10% peer review)

Overview 

This assessment comprises three parts. The first part requires students to write a 1,500 word essay. The second part involves rewriting the essay based on the feedback provided by the lecturer-in-charge. The third part involves peer reviewing a rewritten essay. The lecturer has three weeks to mark all essays. Essays with both comments and a mark will be handed back to students in week TBA. Students have one week (plus mid semester break) to rewrite their essay. Students are to hand in both their original essay with comments and the rewritten essay in week TBA. On this day, the essays will be redistributed to peers and their task is to mark the rewritten essay. Students have one week to complete this task; must hand back peer reviewed essay in week TBA. 

Marking by peers will involve reading the original submission, reading the comments from the lecturer, and finally reading the rewritten submission to ensure all comments have been addressed. Students must write extensive feedback about the rewritten essay, as well as provide a mark out of 10. This mark should reflect the changes made between the original and rewritten essay, based on the comments from the lecturer. Failure to complete any part of the peer review process (provide detailed feedback on assessment using the lecturer's comments from original submission) will result in students forfeiting the 10% mark attributed to this process.    

 

Essay Question

TBA

Due Date

The essay must be submitted using both Moodle as well as providing the Lecturer a hard copy in class prior to TBA.

Additional Information

You need to approach this assessment by attending the weekly lectures, completing the prescribed readings from the text and the tutorial readings/questions at the end of the lectures. 

In order to complete this assessment, you will need to research the chosen topic. This will not only involve consulting lecture notes, but reading relevant texts in the area, as well as journal papers. Remember, this is an academic assignment and information sources such as magazines and the internet (only to access journal papers) are not appropriate.

In brief, it is expected that you complete this assessment by following the ‘Marking Schedule’. This means that you should include (in addition to an assignment cover sheet):

Title,

Abstract,

Introduction,

Body,  

Conclusion, and 

References (as per American Psychological Association (APA) publication guidelines)

 

The essay needs to be formatted as per APA publication guidelines. 

 

*Failure to complete any of the components such as rewriting the essay or peer reviewing a fellow student’s essay will result in the total loss of marks for this component. 

**A late penalty of 10% per day, including weekends will be applied to all late assessments. 

*** Students have an opportunity to contend the mark by their peers if they believe the mark is not supported by the comments. If students wish to contend this mark, they need to do so in the form of a rejoinder. The rejoinder should highlight what changes they have made, the origins of the change, and where the changes feature in the rewritten essay.  

****Any student who does not take the peer review process seriously will forego the marks attributable to this component (i.e., 10%), irrespective of their mark for their rewritten essay. 

Feedback. Feedback will be provided in throught the submission in the form of comments, in addition to a mark out of 10.

contentlets.description: Human performance is highly dependent on a number of factors, some of which are under our direct control while others are outside our sphere of control. Nonetheless, with the correct application of knowledge, planning and design, systems can be designed with the human in mind to facilitate in human performance. This course examines human behaviour from a theoretical perspective, with the intent to optimise the relationship between humans and their environment. With the focus primarily on the individual, this course examines basic human cognition, including perception, memory, information processing, and decision-making. These principles are then applied to the aviation industry to understand the design of systems (i.e., flight deck, consoles, aircraft, etc) for human use.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Human Factors

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3286c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3a86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ea86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f286c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2686c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment One","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This individual assignment constitutes 25% of the total grade. This assignment will be released in Week 1 and is due in class on Week 5. Detailed feedback and marks will be provided to students in class within 2 weeks of submission. This assignment requires individual inquiry, critical thinking, and clear writing. Reports must be properly referenced using APA/ Harvard referencing.

Analysis of 3 routes within the Australian Domestic Market:

Access the BITRE ‘Top Routes’ worksheet https://bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/domestic.aspx

The Assignment questions will be in Moodle and will focus on the abovementioned data source. The
analysis will be limited to the following city pairs:
MEL-SYD,
CBR-SYD,
PER-MEL
You may link your analysis to GDP, population & other data available from ABS or other reputable sources.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3a86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ea86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"928681b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment Two","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This group assignment constitutes 20% of the total grade. This assignment will be released in Week 2 and is due in class on Week 8. Detailed feedback and marks will be provided to students in class within 2 weeks of submission. This assignment requires team work, group contribution, group decision making, comprehensive modelling and analysis, clear convincing presentation of results. Reports must be properly referenced using APA/Harvard referencing.

The Australian and Chinese governments recently signed an open skies agreement. Much of the growth in capacity into/out of Australia has been added by airlines from the Gulf or China. Using ABS, Tourism Australia and BITRE data analyse this shift in traffic. In particular, you should analyse the changes in the markets between Australia and China (including routes to Hong Kong). Consider the broader economic impact of this change in air service connectivity with particular reference to inbound tourism. To achieve this you will need to analyse route and network structure, current pricing strategies and the current fleet structures of the key carriers. All of this data is available from publicly accessible websites. 

Outputs include: 

1. A REPORT FOR THE MANAGEMENT

This report will include: executive summary; the modelling and methodology used; data and sources; any assumptions that you made. Please also attach a summary of group meetings and attendance. 

2. 10-MIN PRESENTATION TO THE CEO

The top 5-7 groups that produced the best reports will be invited to present in class. Presentation will be made by 1-2 group members. Presentation must be effective as you have to persuade the CEO that your analysis is sound. Teams will be allocated in week 1. You can meet immediately in the tutorial time and you must hold a minimum of 5 meetings (you have 7 weeks to complete the assignment).


Recommended structure:

1. Project Lead (1-2 People) – To coordinate the project work and to follow up assigned tasks
2. Analysts (4-5 People) – These people will access, model and collate the data for the report
3. Reporters (The rest of the group) – These people will write the report and access broader supporting information - references - as required.

There will be a peer review.

contentlets.description: This course covers the economics of an airline and how airline management personnel address airline economic problems. Topics include demand analysis and the relation with price and economic condition. Costs and supply are studied with reference to examples where current airline data is available. The interaction of demand and supply are then studied and as are methodologies of how airlines manage this aspect. Both passenger and freight economics are covered. Some introductory study of airline financial matters, product costing and route profitability are covered. Statistical theory applied to airline economic issues is included.
contentlets.title: Aviation Transport Economics

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA1902 - Airline Financial Analysis and Decision Support","description":"

This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the financial decision-making required in the commercial air transport industry. Air transport is capital intensive, and the structure of the industry has seen poor returns on this capital over an extended period. Specifically, this course examines (1) the tools for financial decision-making, and (2) the application of those tools by financial managers of airlines and airports. Topics include making investment decisions, financing choices (including leasing), fleeting planning, route economics, hedging financial risks, and airline financial statements.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d9cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a96199d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Three tutorial quizzes will be administered throughout the term during tutorial sessions. the first 2 quizzes are 12 mulitple choice questions to be completed within a 20 minute duration. The first quiz will occur in week 3 and cover the topics taught in weeks 1 and 2. The second quiz will occur in week 6 and cover the topics taught in weeks 4 and 5.

The third quiz is an online Excel task that must be completed during the tutorial of week 10. The topic covered will be data analystic skills using Microsoft Excel. Students will cover this material throughout the term and have had homework practice questions related to these skills. The duration is 30 minutes. 

All quizzes constitute 10% of the final grade. Students will receive their quiz marks within 1 week of each quiz, and will have the opportunity to view their quiz paper during the course convener's consultation hours.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"01cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"11cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"49cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"95cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d1cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"49cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

This exam is held during the University examination period and is designed to test the student's knowledge of all topics covered in AVIA1902 throughout the term. The exam format consists of a combination of short-answer, essay-style and multiple choice questions. The final exam is 2 hours duration with 10 mins reading time, and constitutes 45% of the final grade. Feedback is not provided as it is an externally managed final exam, but the student will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper if they wish.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"01cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"11cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"49cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"91cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"95cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d1cd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ddcd1ae3dbb99850eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b0cdd6e3dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-Semester Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The mid-semester exam is held in week 6 during class times. It will cover the topics taught throughout the first 5 weeks of term. It is 1 hour in duration with 5 minute reading time. Students will receive their mid-semester mark within 2 weeks of the exam, and will have the opportunity to view their exam paper during the course convener's consultation hours. The exam and its suggested solutions will also be discussed in the following week's tutorial.

The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 1 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying). Included are all theory requirements for the issue of Private Pilot (Aeroplane) Licence (PP(A)L) with night flying privileges, namely Pre-solo Air Legislation, Basic Aeronautical Knowledge, PP(A)L and night flying theory. Students will also cover introductory material in the areas of aircraft engineering and maintenance. This course encompasses Phases 1 - 5 as detailed in the UNSW Manual of Flight Training and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority Day VFR Syllabus - Aeroplane. Practical flying training (AVIASC01) is a highly recommended adjunct to this course.


Note:  Students who commenced program 3980 Aviation (Flying) in semester 1 are assumed to have completed 36 UOC from AVIA1321, AVIA1401, AVIA1901, MATH1031, MATH1041, PHYS1149, PHYS1211, AVEN1920 before enrolment in this course.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA2025 - Introduction to Airborne Drone Management","description":"

Airborne drones (unmanned aerial vehicles (or remotely piloted aircraft (RPA)) of varying shapes and sizes are permeating the civil aviation sector across recreational, commercial and research activities. The professional ability to safely and efficiently operate and manage airborne drones requires fundamental aviation knowledge. This course will introduce these fundamentals of RPA management to students through a suite of topics including basic aeronautical knowledge, RPA ethics and law, human factors and safety, logistics and operations, and RPA research methods. The course will emphasise practical applications of the concepts and tools introduced through select case studies and realistic mission planning for operations involving commercial and research activities.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"df848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619af","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short answer questions","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This assignment covers the main topics introduced in Unit1-6. This will be delivered as a number of online short answer assessment items during the semester to act as both a mechanism for students to check their understanding of the material and as a small assessment item. The emphasis will be on understanding the core concepts the course subsequently builds on in the later units.

Grading will be completed within 2 weeks of submission. Feedback from this assessment will be used to guide and teach students towards the case study report and final exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1f848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"83848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a96199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cf848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case study report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This report will require students to apply concepts learnt to plan and assess a realistic remotely piloted aircraft mission for commercial activity. The assignment requires students consult a mix of multimedia, industry, government, and academic sources. Grading will be completed within 3 weeks of submission. 

Student work will be judged on the comprehensiveness of the plan, gathering of correct information and accuracy in the use of the information. Students will be asked to pitch the mission proposal in a form of short video, which will be assessed on presentation clarity and accuracy. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1f848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5b848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"83848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a96199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"97848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cf848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d3848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76848d3fdb391c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The exam covers all topics in the course. The purpose of the exam is to test student understanding of the concepts and tools learnt in remotely piloted aircraft governance, operations and research. Students will be encouraged to demonstrate their understanding of theoretical knowledge through the use of original examples.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA2101 - Baggage Handling System Design, Technology & Operations","description":"

A good working baggage handling system is essential for the functioning of modern airports. This course builds on the general knowledge of aviation gained in first year and explores the design, technology and operations of baggage handling systems at airports. 


The course consists of three phases. The first phase introduces the baggage handling process and its operational aspects, in particular, the interactions between the different stages of the process. The second phase focuses on the latest developments in baggage handling systems technology and the changes made to the baggage handling process, such as the application of RFID and biometric technology. The last phase deals with design processes and system analyses. The Delft systems approach and design methods will be introduced to students, enabling them to analyse the baggage handling process and to conceptually design a baggage handling system. 


Throughout the course, all aspects of baggage handling systems will be analysed from different perspectives: the designer of the overall system, the component supplier, the airport, the airline, customs and the passengers. The course concludes with two assignments that allow students to put the theory in practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"84fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961992","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The second assignment is a group assignment. This assignment is an actual conceptual design challenge in the area of automated baggage handling systems. Although this assignment is a group assignment, students will be assessed individually. The final product of this assignment are a report (written by the group), in which the groups describe and motivate their design, and a final presentation. Each student will be responsible for a chapter in the final report enabling individual assessment. In addition, each student will have to give a presentation during the course in which they present the progress the group made during the previous week. Feedback will be given on both the report, the progress presentations and the final presentation.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0cfdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"48fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4cfdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"88fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3edf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ffedf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37edf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are provided with a set of 12 multiple choice questions at the beginning of the semester. These will cover the first 3 weeks of course materials and will be due before the Census Date. The questions will focus on primarily BHS operations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0cfdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4cfdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3edf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3edf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The first assignment is an assignment that students will do individually. The assignment concerns the (re)design of a baggage handling system for a rural airport in South Africa and concerns primarily the BHS equipment and technology selection. This assignment should be finished by mid-term. The final product of this assignment is a report that each students writes. Feedback will be given on each report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0cfdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"48fdf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3edf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ffedf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ebedf8fbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961959","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA2101.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the grant of an instrument rating, specifically the IREX and GNSS units of competency.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b1d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96198c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"IFR exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

15 sets of 40 questions each are completed both in the third week of class and outside of class. The particular, specific and difficult nature of the external exam, which pilots must pass, requires significant practice in solving scenario based problems.

\n

Feedback is given by the lecturer within one hour of submission by a detailed analysis of each students problem areas.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"65d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fdd045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"55d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"UNSW IFR exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

2 papers of 40 multiple questions each conducted at the Flying Operations Unit. Exam style, scope and conditions similar to the external exam required by federal licensing and accreditation requirements.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"65d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fdd045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"add045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96195b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"CASA IREX","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

A federally mandated examination conducted by the aviation regulator external to UNSW, required for pilots to achieve an instrument rating on their flight crew licence.

\n

Feedback is generated by the regulator immediately at the conclusion of the exam in accordance with legislation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"65d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fdd045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5d045f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA2117.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Aviation Law and Regulations","description":"

This course aims to provide students with an overview of the regulatory structure of civil aviation in Australia. The subject focuses on the legal system within which this regulatory system operates and the powers, responsibilities and scope of the various aviation regulatory authorities. In particular the subject will concentrate on providing a practical insight into the legal implications associated with various aviation personnel including the pilot-in-command.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b13992e7db799850eb6b147a3a961924","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Legal Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This is a 500 word individual assignment to be released in Week 1 and to be submitted in Week 3. This assessment item comprises 10% of the final grade. The essay question will be based on the Australian legal system and aviation law. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle and in class within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"293992e7db799850eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"653992e7db799850eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b53992e7db799850eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"193952e7db799850eb6b147a3a9619ec","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The mid-semester exam will be held in week 6 during class time. It will comprise of 40 multiple choice questions and cover all topics taught from Week 1 to Week 5, inclusive. This assessment item constitutes 40% of the final grade. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle and in class by Week 8. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"293992e7db799850eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"653992e7db799850eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b13992e7db799850eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"613952e7db799850eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam is worth 50% of the final grade. This exam will be held during the exam period. All topics covered throughout the term will be assessed. The format of the exam is a combination os multiple choice and short-answer (essay style) questions. Students will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper and receive feedback from the course convenor.

contentlets.description: This course uses the classic approach to marketing management strategies but is entirely focused on how this is achieved in the airline industry. The approach is of a practical nature. The course studies airline market research, marketing strategy development, product development, pricing strategies and revenue management, distribution and promotion strategies. The course encourages and emphasises current airline marketing behaviour as examples of the theory. Passenger and freight marketing are included.
contentlets.title: Airline Marketing Strategies

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA2601","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA2601 - Aviation Operations Research","description":"

This course aims to introduce students with Operations Research (OR) concepts in the aviation context. Topics include: fundamentals of OR, network models, general OR models, aviation scheduling, corporate optimisation, decision science in aviation context, fleet assignment, aircraft routing, and other relevant models. Data analytics is included to provide students with knowledge and skills on data preparation, data exploration and data modelling. Students are provided with computer programming training and tutorial sessions, and this is an essential and significant part of this course. Assessments are based on group projects so to train teamwork and communication skills in team projects.

Students are required to build a fleet assignment model (FAM) and an aircraft routing model (AR). Feedback will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"78de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b4de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f0de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2- AR, CP and CR","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to build an aircraft routing model (AR) following Assignment Two. Then, the AR model is used to build a crew pairing model (CP) and to build a crew rostering model (CR). Feedback will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission.

Students' programming skills will be tested by this data modelling project. A dataset will be provided to students for this project and students are required to conduct this project by using newly acquired skills and knowledge to explore data and conduct data analysis. Feeback will be provided in the classroom during tutorial sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"30de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7cde96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e8de96a7dbb99850eb6b147a3a96199e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA2601.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course aims to introduce students with Operations Research (OR) concepts in the aviation context. Topics include: fundamentals of OR, network models, general OR models, aviation scheduling, corporate optimisation, decision science in aviation context, fleet assignment, aircraft routing, and other relevant models. Data analytics is included to provide students with knowledge and skills on data preparation, data exploration and data modelling. Students are provided with computer programming training and tutorial sessions, and this is an essential and significant part of this course. Assessments are based on group projects so to train teamwork and communication skills in team projects.
contentlets.title: Aviation Operations Research

The first component of this course provides a framework for understanding how airports function, the many demands placed upon them by a wide range of stakeholders and what is needed for airports to be successful at both an operational and business level. Students will gain insights into the major issues facing airport managers today This course offers a mix of Facilitator lectures and Guest presentations - students will gain valuable insights from current experts in their field The major student assignment will require students to immerse themselves in a specific airport - to understand the basic business and operational functions of the airport.


The second component of this course covers Aviation Security. As the aviation industry grows so too does the potential for terrorist and criminal activities against the industry. Aviation has been and continues to be an attractive target for terrorists, including the recent attacks against airports and aircraft operators. Students will learn about the complex set of procedures and activities that, when brought together, results in a secure and efficient transport system. Students will also cover case studies of how interruptions to that system, such Pan Am flight 108, 9/11, the Brussels Airport attack or even the Sydney aircraft plot of July 2017 can and will have far reaching effects on public confidence and their expectations, government oversight, delays and costs to industry, and the potential for loss of live and suffering.



 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6786c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pre-census date quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

This is a formative quiz that is held in Week 3 to provide students with feedback on their progress. Students are given the opportunity to receive detailed feedback from the Course Convener during consultation hours or by appointment. This assessment item has no impact on the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2b86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1786c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam will be held during the exam period. It will be a 2 hour exam consisting of 40 mulitple choice questions and 3 short answer essay-style questions. This exam constitutes 50% of the final grade. Students will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper and receive detailed feedback. 

The essay portion of the exam will be marked for relevance of the topic, the strength of the examples provided to support any argument or position as well for any regulatory references. Marks will also be allocated for the overall ability to get across the issues in a concise and informative manner.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2b86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2f86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6786c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6b86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a386c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ef86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 2000-word essay on the students' understanding of how airports function at both the operational and business level. The essay question will be released in class in Week 2. The essay is to be submitted via Moodle in Week 5. This essay constitutes 30% of the final grade. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2b86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6786c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db86c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4786c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class Online Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

20 multiple choice questions to be answered within 25 minutes in the tutorial class of Week 8. This quiz will cover the concepts of Australia's aviation security as covered in Weeks 6 and 7. Marks will be calculated immediately via Moodle. Students are able to retrieve detailed feedback from the course convener during consultation hours. This quiz constitutes 20% of the final grade.

This course covers the broad range of management decisions faced within the general, corporate and regional aviation sectors and how that is impacted by Government and regulation. The aviation environment within which management functions and make economic decisions are introduced. How this sector is regulated and the impact of those regulations on the Sector is studied. Technical issues are discussed; competition, revenue, costs and pricing are considered. The management and operation of Regional airports, recreational aviation, Remotely
Piloted Aircraft (drones) and of flying training schools are examined. Case studies on specific Regional airlines and airports are presented and discussed.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"289605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a96193d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a group assignment and will involve students submitting a consulting report and presenting their findings in the final week of class. Groups will be assigned in Week 5 of class. The consulting report is to be submitted in class in Week 10. The purpose of this group assignment is to demonstrate the students' understanding of the underlying strategic issues, operational and financial constraints and the ability to determine a realistic solution. Students will also have to showcase their ability to develop and present a convincing case to an audience. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 1 week of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2c9605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"549605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a09605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ec9605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0896c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

The exam will cover all concepts taught in AVIA2801. This is a 2 hour exam that consists of multiple choice and short-answer essay based question. This exam will be held during the UNSW Examination Period. Students will be given the opportunity to see the course convener during consultations hours after the exam to view their exam paper and receive feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2c9605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"549605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a09605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ec9605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4096c1b3db791c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pre-census Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

This is a formative quiz that is held in Week 3 to provide students with feedback on their progress. Students are given the opportunity to receive detailed feedback from the Course Convener during consultation hours or by appointment. This assessment item has no impact on the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"549605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"589605b3db791c50eb6b147a3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This is a 1500-word individual report on one of the contemporary issues facing Australia's aviation industry today. Students will be give the opportunity to select the topic of their assignment in Week 2 of class. This assessment will be submitted in Week 5. Students are to express their views and recommendations in the report, and conduct desk research and analysis. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students in class within 2 weeks of submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA2910","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA2910 - Air Transport: Economics and the Environment","description":"

This course is designed to develop non-economics majors’ economic literacy in the understanding of the key drivers of the commercial air transport industry and the industries’ impact on society. The course builds on the principles of economics to examine contemporary and prominent issues in the aviation-environment nexus such as aircraft noise and climate change. Specifically, the course examines the inter-related nature of air transport and other sectors of an economy, and the interactions of air transport with broader socio-economic, tourism and environmental issues. Students will be encouraged to apply concepts and techniques learnt in class through a short field excursion and series of tutorials on basic econometrics. The course will encourage students to think about air transport from varying perspectives on sustainable development. 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"34ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961920","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual post-fieldtrip report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are required to write-up a 3-page report to demonstrate their understanding of the link between economic theories introduced in the course and the field-work. 

The individual report will be graded via Turnitin grading rubric. An individual mark will be given via Turnitin, and overall written feedback will be given to the class. All assessments will be graded within 2 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"38ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6cea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"70ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b8ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bcea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f4ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f8ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24eaeee7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

The final exam will assess student level of understanding and knowledge through short answers and short essay questions. One of the exam questions also requires a short article to be read. All materials introduced in the course are assessable. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"34ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6cea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"70ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b8ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bcea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f4ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f8ea222bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6ceaeee7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group report: hedonic price model of aircraft noise","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to undertake an empirical modelling project that aims to attribute monetary value to aircraft noise using simulated data of Sydney house prices. 

For the group assignment, students will be required to submit a group work contract. The group assignment will be graded and will be sent to the group members along with comments.

contentlets.description: This course is designed to develop non-economics majors’ economic literacy in the understanding of the key drivers of the commercial air transport industry and the industries’ impact on society. The course builds on the principles of economics to examine contemporary and prominent issues in the aviation-environment nexus such as aircraft noise and climate change. Specifically, the course examines the inter-related nature of air transport and other sectors of an economy, and the interactions of air transport with broader socio-economic, tourism and environmental issues. Students will be encouraged to apply concepts and techniques learnt in class through a short field excursion and series of tutorials on basic econometrics. The course will encourage students to think about air transport from varying perspectives on sustainable development.
contentlets.title: Air Transport: Economics and the Environment

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA2950 - Current Affairs in Aviation","description":"

Be up to date with the latest in the aviation industry, both globally and locally. This course looks at the politics and the economics driving the aviation industry today and the business dynamics which are dramatically changing the face of that industry.  Learn how the industry is regulated internationally and in Australia; and how that influences the business climate in which airlines operate. Discover the huge economic contribution that aviation makes, both directly and indirectly.  Hear from executives and others currently working in the industry about how airlines and airports are run, the big issues that they face and what technology contributes.  Find out about advertising and branding, and how the media reports on the industry, to see how public opinion is influenced.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"feb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a96199c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

The final exam is held during the UNSW Exam Period. It is 2 hours in length, and covers all materials taught throughout semester. The format of the exam consists of short-answer questions and two essay questions. Students will be given the opportunity after the exam to view their examp paper and receive detailed feedback during the course convener's consultation hours. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2eb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ab92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b6b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eeb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"26b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group report: Assessing the drivers for change in airline seat offering","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are to work in groups and prepare a 15 minute presentation on a contemporary issue in Australia's aviation industry. Topics to be released to students in Week 2. Groups will be formed randomly via Moodle in Week 2. The presentations will be held in class in Week 9 of class. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle within 1 week of presentation. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2eb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eeb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5eb92e27db3d9850eb6b147a3a961946","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Research paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a 1500-word critique on a select guest lecture, with the following questions posed: "What were the issues? What is being done to address them? Do you agree or disagree and why?". Students must inform the course convener of the topic of their assignment by Week 6. Assignment is to be submitted in Week 7. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided in class within 2 week of submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA3013","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA3013 - Workplace Safety","description":"

The ways in which work can affect people's health, safety and well-being is an important consideration for all organisations. Accordingly, an understanding of workplace safety issues is important for students pursuing careers in any industry. This course explores the legal frameworks, current methodologies and issues of best practice in the prevention and management of workplace hazards. The course uses a variety of media for course material and assessment, including websites, videos and case studies, and builds on students’ own workplace experiences. It is anticipated that students will gain an appreciation of current legislation and codes of practice, identify different types of workplace hazards and understand how they can affect people; and be able to apply the risk management approach to workplace hazards.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4ec95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619eb","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Group project based on a real incidents/scenarios, where students are asked to perform the role of consultants and report on what systemic changes are needed to improve safety outcomes. 
Comments on report, consistent with stated marking criteria.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"06c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"42c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"79c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b5c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f1c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f5c95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2dc95a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Hazard report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are asked to identify hazards or hazardous tasks/scenarios in their own workplace; or if they do not work, interview someone who does. Students can also talk more generally about their experience of workplace safety (e.g., training they have undertaken, systems in their workplace) and identify better risk controls. They are asked to submit a short video answering the question.
Responses are shared with other students electronically to encourage discussion and learning from new scenarios.

The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 3 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying). Included are all theory requirements for the issue of an Air Transport Pilot (Aeroplane) Licence (ATP(A)L), taught as seven discrete modules. Additionally, the course covers the aeronautical theory required to support the various elective components of the course selected by the student. Electives are Flight Instructor Rating, Airline experience, Multi-crew cooperation training, General Aviation, or a Research project. This course encompasses Phases 9 - 12 as detailed in the UNSW Manual of Flight Training, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority Part 61 Manual of Standards. Practical flying training (AVIASC13) is a highly recommended adjunct to this course.

contentlets.description: The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 3 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying). Included are all theory requirements for the issue of an Air Transport Pilot (Aeroplane) Licence (ATP(A)L), taught as seven discrete modules. Additionally, the course covers the aeronautical theory required to support the various elective components of the course selected by the student. Electives are Flight Instructor Rating, Airline experience, Multi-crew cooperation training, General Aviation, or a Research project. This course encompasses Phases 9 - 12 as detailed in the UNSW Manual of Flight Training, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority Part 61 Manual of Standards. Practical flying training (AVIASC13) is a highly recommended adjunct to this course.

contentlets.description: This course considers the main facets of corporate airline management, and begins with airline organisational practice, management's visions and objective setting. It proceeds with the main corporate processes of business planning, schedule planning, fleet planning and external relationships such as outsourcing. Financial aspects and global alliance matters are introduced.
contentlets.title: Airline Management

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA3201","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA3201 - Airline Resource Management","description":"

Airline operations are defined as the functional areas which are directly associated with the operations of aircraft or at least in the provision of services for aircraft operations. There is much overlap between the management of the ‘corporate’ aspects of the airline and the operational aspects. This occurs mainly in the planning processes such as fleet planning, schedule planning, and strategic planning (including business plans and annual budgets). These important processes will be covered in this subject for the functional areas that play major roles in an airline, especially resources allocation and utilisation. Engineering and maintenance, airline operations and scheduling, and crew resource provision are three major topics that are covered in detail in this course.


Other airline processes are also covered in this course and play important roles in operations. These include operations control, air cargo and punctuality management. General management techniques apply to many of these functional areas. Planning, budgeting, staffing, equipment rostering, and disruption management are generic but in this course, these topics are discussed from the airline’s view.

contentlets.description:
Airline operations are defined as the functional areas which are directly associated with the operations of aircraft or at least in the provision of services for aircraft operations. There is much overlap between the management of the ‘corporate’ aspects of the airline and the operational aspects. This occurs mainly in the planning processes such as fleet planning, schedule planning, and strategic planning (including business plans and annual budgets). These important processes will be covered in this subject for the functional areas that play major roles in an airline, especially resources allocation and utilisation. Engineering and maintenance, airline operations and scheduling, and crew resource provision are three major topics that are covered in detail in this course.

Other airline processes are also covered in this course and play important roles in operations. These include operations control, air cargo and punctuality management. General management techniques apply to many of these functional areas. Planning, budgeting, staffing, equipment rostering, and disruption management are generic but in this course, these topics are discussed from the airline’s view.
contentlets.title: Airline Resource Management

Simulation Application and Air Traffic Management","description":"

The first component of this course addresses the broad application of simulation to training in the aviation industry. While the emphasis will be on aircraft simulations, aspects of air traffic control simulation will also be included. Perspectives from both the trainer and trainees will be considered, and benefits to aviation safety identified. While pilots have to control a single aircraft, air traffic controllers deal with many. The ATM component of this course will identify the practical needs for air traffic management in terms of operational efficiency and safety. Topics will include administrative and operational structures, from the perspective of the air traffic manager. Future systems will also be discussed.


The second component of this course provides an introduction to ATM (Air Traffic Management) including subcomponents associated with the practical management of the flow of air traffic safely and efficiently. Topics include an overview of ATC (Air Traffic Control) operational structures, ATC operational systems and highlevel ATC procedures related to the management of increasing air traffic demand through airspace and airports.

This assignment consists of 10 short answer questions, and constitutes 25% of the final grade. This is expected to be approximately 1500 words in length. The assignment will cover the first 3 weeks of material taught in the Simulation Applications component (first 5 weeks) of the course. This assignment will be released in Week 2 and is due in Week 5. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle and student consultation (by appointment) within 2 weeks of submission.

This assignment is a group assignment based on the first 2 weeks of the Air Traffic Management components of the course (second half of the course). This assignment will be released in Week 6 and is due on Week 7. Groups will be formed randomly on Moodle and students notified via email. This assignment comprises 5% of the total grade. The assignment question will be released on Moodle in Week 5. The word count should not exceed 700 words. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle and student consultation (by appointment) within 2 weeks of submission.
