This assignment is individual assignment to be released in Week 7 and to be submitted in Week 10. This assignment comprises 20% of the total grade. The assignment question will be released on Moodle in Week 7 - it will be based on air traffic management and concepts covered in weeks 5 to 8. The word count should not exceed 2000 words. Extensive research and analyses will be required. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle and student consultation (by appointment) within 2 weeks of submission.

The final exam will comprise of all Simulation Applications and Air traffic Management topics covered in the course, and will be a combination of multiple choice and short-answer essay questions. This assessment item will cover all topics taught in the course, and will be held during the exam period. The final exam constitutes 50% of the final grade. Students will be given the opportunity to view their exam paper and receive feedback from the course convenor.

Assessment 2: Analysis of organisational human factors (15%)

Overview 

Written individual assignment worth 15% and due week 8. Students are to submit a hard copy to the lecturer. The content of this assessment must relate to the topics and material covered into this course 

 

Detail 

First, search, monitor and bookmark internet news stories concerning human factors in transportation that cover the themes of the various topics covered in this course. The news stories must be English-language stories from reputable, international, national or regional news agencies or newspapers or even accident investigation bodies (e.g. Associated Press, Reuters, The Australian, Sydney Morning Herald, BBC News, The Times, The Guardian, The New York Times, The Washington Post, ATSB website, NTSB website, etc). The publication must be no older than one year (ideally less than six months) prior to the start of the course, but can be of any date during the course. 

 

Individuals are required to select only one story and:

  • cite the article title (exactly from the source),
  • provide a concise summary/synopsis of the story that is no longer than 50 words, and
  • relate the content or themes of the story to the material in the related Unit/s of the course by integrating references to scholarly literature (e.g. books, and journals).

You may of course use additional references that are not included in the course materials as required readings. You must reference at least six HF/safety reference sources for each story. Concentrate on integrating new scholarly material rather than repeating facts about the event/story (maximum total word count, not including references per story/event is 1,000).  

 

There is no need to provide an introduction or a conclusion in the assignment. However, you must provide a list of references for the news stories/event and the scholarly literature sources that you have cited. It is recommended that you structure your assignment roughly as follows: 

  1. UNSW Aviation assignment cover sheet, 
  2. Title page, 
  3. Headline of news article, then brief synopsis followed by HF/safety analysis, 
  4. List of References; remember; there should be at least six references. References must be cited and formatted in APA (American Psychological Association) style. 

Remember the word limit is 1,000 words per story, excluding the cover sheet, title page and list of references. Please state the word count on the title page. Marks will be deducted for assignments exceeding the word limit. 

The submission date is week 8. 

Applications for an extension of time must be made in writing prior to the due date. Late assignments, without a reason deemed satisfactory by the lecturer, will be penalised by a loss of 10% of the total possible marks for the assignment per day, including weekends. 

Finally, no two written submissions can be on the same topic/accident. Hence, I have created a scheduling calendar using Doodle which you will be invited to participate in (following week 2). It remains your responsibility to note the following information. Surname, Topic Area. Hence, prior to uploading the above details, check to see that your topic is unique. If two topics area are found to be the same, the article that was uploaded second will receive a zero mark.

Example of topic area- Asiana FL 214, Germanwings FL 9525, etc. 

***Remember, the topic (accident) of your article needs to be unique. ***

Feeback.

Students will be provided feedback in the form of comments written on their submission in addition to a mark. Feedback will be provided within two weeks of submission.

Assessment 3 – Movie presentation (group project) 15%

Aim – The aim of this assessment (from an academic perspective) is twofold. 

  1. Group Performance. This assessment is designed to build and or enhance team skills, such as: management skills, delegation skills, communication skills, and leadership skills. 
  2. Area/topic knowledge. This assessment is designed to foster in the development of knowledge in an aviation specific area. 

In pursuit of these two aims, this assessment contains a number of milestones which must be met by students. The obvious milestone is the completion and presentation of the movie (i.e., video). In addition, students are expected to keep detailed minutes of every meeting (ideally secretary take notes and distribute to all team member). These minutes must include, although not limited to:

  1. Meeting date,
  2. Note attendees,
  3. Note roles assigned to team members,
  4. Note tasks assigned to team members,
  5. Document when assigned tasks are due,
  6. Document completion of assigned tasks, and
  7. Document reasons why assigned tasks were not completed, etc.

Students will be assessed on these milestones. In week 10, students will present their video along with minutes from each meeting in hard copy (handed to lecturer). As highlighted above, the minutes should include information pertaining to the above seven points (at a minimum). 

 

 

Steps Required to Successfully Pass Assessment 

Step 1

Complete movie 

Step 2

Be present for movie presentation (15%)

Step 3

Provide evidence of Team Work in the form of minutes from each meeting

 

Assessment 3: Movie Presentation plus Questions (Group Project; 15%)

Overview 

Students are required to work in small groups and create a 5 minute movie focusing on an error producing situation, equipment or rule/procedure/SOP. The movie must be played during class in the final week. Five (5) minutes following the movie has been allocated for questions. This assessment is worth 15%.  

 

Detail

Following the census date, students will be allocated to a group with approximately 5-6 members. The groups must work cohesively to create a five minute movie to be played during class in the final week. The content of the movie will be based on an error producing situation/s, equipment or rule/procedure/SOP, as elected by the group. In doing so, it is expected that each group cover at least the following:

  • clearly explain the item under examination, 
  • its purpose, 
  • the perceived flaw or limitation, 
  • how it could present a trap (or is a hazard), 
  • the likely outcome of interacting with the item,
  • how it could be modified or improved, 
  • what systems are in place to capture or mitigate the risks associated with interacting with the item and resulting in an adverse outcome, and
  • what system/s should be in place to mitigate the risks associated with the item in question. 

 

Groups must be ready to present their movie at the start of class during the final week. The movie must last for five minutes. After the movie, class members will have an opportunity to ask questions. All group members must both feature in the movie as well as be present for the presentation and question time. Failure to feature in the movie and/or be present for the presentation will automatically result in the absent student/s receiving a zero mark for the assessment. Finally, students are to provide a copy of the minutes from each meeting. Students will be assessed on both the movie (see presentation marking guide) and the minutes.

Feedback. Student will be provided feedback about their presentation in the form of a written response, including a mark out of 10. This will be sent via email no later than one week following the presentation.

Assessment 1: Progress Test (25%)

The aim of this assignment is to encourage students to attend all lectures, and tutorials as well as read the required readings/text each week. Hence, a progress test will be conducted during week 5. The test will take the form of multiple-choice questions. All material up until week 5 will be examined, including material presented in lectures, tutorials and the required readings. 

Feedback. Feedback will be provided in the form of the correct answers and topic under examination. Feedback will be provided within two weeks of the assessement submission.

contentlets.description: The success of safe operations within aviation relies as much on the individual performing his/her role, as on the way he/she interacts with others. This course, therefore, examines the interaction of people in a group or set of groups and examines how this interaction affects the performance of the system, and the relative success of the operations. Theories relating to group-based behaviour and performance, including social and cultural aspects, organisational and safety culture are examined. The application of these theories as discussed in context to a number of high profile aviation accidents/incidents.
contentlets.title: Aviation Safety and Resource Management

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA3410","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA3410 - Advanced Law and Regulation in Aviation","description":"

The course aims to provide students with a deeper understanding of contemporary aviation law and associated regulations by focusing in greater detail aspects of the course content covered in AVIA2401 by exploring judicial and regulatory developments of both international and domestic case law which is of particular relevance to the contemporary globalized context in which aviation operates. The course further aims to equip students with an understanding of the difficulties the various courts and regulators face when trying to keep pace with rapid technological advancements and global growth within the industry.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3fe63c3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96199a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 1500 word report on the lagging legislation on unmanned aerial vehicle. The assignment question will be released in class in Week 2. The assignment si to be submitted in Moodle via Turnitin in Week 4. This assignment consititutes 25% of the final grade. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students in class 2 weeks within time of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6be63c3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5be63c3bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 2500 word report on a contemporary case study on legislation and changes in technology in the avition industry. The assignment question will be released in class in Week 4. The assignment si to be submitted in Moodle via Turnitin in Week 8. This assignment consititutes 35% of the final grade. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students in class 2 weeks within time of submission.

The final exam is held during the UNSW Exam Period. It is 2 hours in length, and covers all materials taught throughout semester. The format of the exam consists of short-answer questions and two essay questions. Students will be given the opportunity after the exam to view their examp paper and receive detailed feedback during the course convener's consultation hours. This assessment constitutes 40% of the final grade.

Basic research skills are important to the aviation industry. The course coaches students through a basic research and report writing process in the context of aviation. Each student undertakes a structured, supervised research project on an aviation safety issue, with specific reference to human, organisational and technical factors.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d9aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The mid-semester exam is held in week 6 during class times. It will cover the topics taught throughout the first 5 weeks of term. It is 1 hour in duration with 5 minute reading time. Students will receive their mid-semester mark within 2 weeks after the exam, and will have the opportunity to view their exam paper during the course convener's consultation hours. The exam and its suggested solutions will also be discussed in the following week's tutorial.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"89aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Question","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

A brief description of the identified research problem and specific research question.  This should be no longer than ONE PAGE (at least 1.5 spaced, 12 point font).  It  needs to include :

  • a Title,
  • a section providing a clear argument for the aviation problem that you want to address and,
  • end with a clear statement of the aim of the project and the research question you plan

Students will receive individual feedback within 2 weeks after submission date. General feedback about the assessment will also be discussed in the following week's tutorial.

 

    ","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9daa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b8aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"55","description":"

    This is the major Assessment of this course.  It should be a formal Research Proposal no longer than 3,000 words (around 10 pages, double spaced, 12 point font), not including References. It needs to include:

    Literature Review: Critically review at least 5 journal articles relevant to the identified research problem and present an argument that justifies the research question.  This section should end with a statement of your research aim and objective(s)

    Proposed Methods and analysis: Describe the research methods you will undertake to answer your research question.  This section should include information on the study design, participants, equipment or data, procedure to be used to conduct the study and data analysis plan

    Expected results and interpretation of findings: Provide  a short description of how you will interpret your findings depending on what your results show and the potential impact of your findings on this area of research

     References: List here all of the journal articles you used for your literature review, and any other literature you cite in the Proposal

    Students will receive individual feedback within 3 weeks after submission date

    ","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"19aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"41aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9daa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d9aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c1aa66e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961949","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA3710.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"AVIA3851","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA3851 - Airport Management 2","description":"

This course follows from AVIA2701 and provides an in-depth coverage of the key elements outlined in the Airport Management component of AVIA2701. Issues include the regulatory environment, including licensing and obligations, an evaluation of various ownership models, the economics of running the airport as a business, including costs, revenues, subsidies and performance indicators, client relations and services, and general airport administration. Airside operations include practical operational requirements as well as necessary documentation. Other planning issues include managing terminal and landside operations, emergency and crisis management, infrastructure development, socio-economic impacts on the community, and environmental impacts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1460bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of session examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

The final exam is held during the UNSW Exam Period. It is 2 hours in length, and covers all materials taught throughout semester. The format of the exam consists of short-answer questions and two essay questions. Students will be given the opportunity after the exam to view their examp paper and receive detailed feedback during the course convener's consultation hours. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0c60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cc60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3b50bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critique of a Guest Speaker Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will write a 1000-word critique essay on a guest lecturer's presentation. This assessment item will assess the student's ability to critically evaluate expert opinions. This is due in Week 9 and is to be submitted via Moodle. Students are to inform the course convener of the proposed topic by Week 8. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0c60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cc60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7350bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation on Second Sydney Airport","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are to form groups in Week 6 for the Group Presentation assignment. It is a 15 minute presentation to be held in Week 10 during class time. Various topics will be released in Week 6 for students to chosoe from, all concerning the second Sydney Airport currently being built. Questions will include the economic, operational, customer and community impact of the airport. Marks and detailed feedback for this assessment task will be released via Moodle iwthin 1 week of submission.

This course offers an introduction to concepts and tools necessary for understanding the challenges of sustainable development in the transport-environment-tourism nexus. Students will develop skills in comprehending and assessing the environmental, social and economic sustainability of societal decisions in the context of tourism. A field excursion to Lady Elliott Island – located in the Southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef - will be undertaken with the objective of allowing students to develop an understanding of these societal trade-offs. The field-based learning will emphasise teamwork, as well as independent observational and enquiry skills using remote eco-resort as a context. Topics will include issues at the interface of transport and tourism management and sustainable development principles. Students will engage in preparatory learning leading up to the excursion, as well as reflective learning through assignments during- and post-trip. Around 24 hours of class, including education tours, fieldwork and presentations, are delivered on the island during the field excursion. This is a summer intensive course. Students should be aware that additional costs associated with the field trip will be incurred including return airfare to Lady Elliott Island (LEI), accommodation and food. This course is also available as an elective course in Science (SCIF3900). 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2ba08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Take home final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

All theoretical and empirical work in the course will be assessable. The take-home exam will be a mix of short-answer questions and essays.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"63a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d7a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"efa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a961993","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be allocated scientific papers on sustainable tourism management. Each student will be required to submit summaries of the scientific papers. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2fa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d7a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"eba08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"efa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field based assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete a collection of tasks during the field excursion such as mapping and writing field notes. Field notes will involve activities such as observing and finding information about the challenges and solutions in operational and logistic management, waste management, and general sustainable destination management practices in the context of a remote tourism resort. Mapping tasks will involve identifying and drawing key geographical characteristics such as land forms, vegetation, as well as evidence of human-impact. Students will also be assessed on the fundamentals of map presentation. For the field assignments, the focus will be on developing the capacity to undertake independent observation and enquiry skills. A predetermined criteria will be used for instructors and peers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2fa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"63a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"afa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d7a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"eba08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"efa08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c7a08db3db391c50eb6b147a3a96198e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA3900.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: aviation,great barrier reef,sustainable tourism logistics,transport and physical geography,protected area management,regional australia,ecotourism
contentlets.description: This course offers an introduction to concepts and tools necessary for understanding the challenges of sustainable development in the transport-environment-tourism nexus. Students will develop skills in comprehending and assessing the environmental, social and economic sustainability of societal decisions in the context of tourism. A field excursion to Lady Elliott Island – located in the Southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef - will be undertaken with the objective of allowing students to develop an understanding of these societal trade-offs. The field-based learning will emphasise teamwork, as well as independent observational and enquiry skills using remote eco-resort as a context. Topics will include issues at the interface of transport and tourism management and sustainable development principles. Students will engage in preparatory learning leading up to the excursion, as well as reflective learning through assignments during- and post-trip. Around 24 hours of class, including education tours, fieldwork and presentations, are delivered on the island during the field excursion. This is a summer intensive course. Students should be aware that additional costs associated with the field trip will be incurred including return airfare to Lady Elliott Island (LEI), accommodation and food. This course is also available as an elective course in Science (SCIF3900).
contentlets.title: Sustainable aviation and tourism

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA3910 - Environmental Performance Evaluation of Aviation: Theories and Techniques","description":"

This course will focus on helping students acquire scientific literacy, aviation knowledge and skills in environmental performance evaluation within the aviation sector. This will be achieved through the study of operational and technological dimensions of environmental sustainability in airport operation, airspace and air traffic management, flight planning, aircraft and renewable fuels. The course will emphasise practical applications of the concepts and tools introduced through select case studies of industry relevance. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to form scientifically informed perspectives to navigate the public, industry and policy discourse on aviation and environmental management. The course builds and reinforces the knowledge for aviation students, science and non-science students wishing to broaden their knowledge base and undertake further studies and research in this area.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"073de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Early term test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This assignment covers the main topics introduced in Unit1-3. This will be delivered as a number of online short answer assessment items at the end of Week 3 to act as both a mechanism for students to check their understanding of the material and as an assessment item. The emphasis will be on understanding the core concepts the course subsequently builds on in the later units. Grading will be completed within 1 week of submission. Feedback from this assessment will be used to guide and teach students towards the group report and final exam. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

The exam covers all topics in the course with greater weight towards Week 4-10. The purpose of the exam is to test the precision and depth of student comprehension of the concepts and techniques learnt, and their understanding of the interrelations among these theories and methods. Students will be encouraged to demonstrate their understanding of theoretical and practical knowledge through the use of original examples. Consequently, the exam will involve a mix of numerical and written questions (e.g., short paragraphs).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"0b3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"433de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8f3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cb3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a3de1f7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This report will require students to apply concepts learnt to assess the environmental dimension of a given aviation activity. The assignment requires students consult a mix of industry, government, and academic sources. Grading will be completed within 2 weeks of submission. 

\n

Student work will be judged on the correct and critical application of tools, as well as the accurate interpretation of information. In addition to the written report, students will be asked to prepare a 3 minute video presentation of the report, which will be assessed on presentation clarity and capacity to prioritise key information.

contentlets.description:
This course introduces students to major research areas through a course of advanced lectures and a major research thesis of 20,000 words. Through the taught component of this course, students will critically examine academic and industry developments within aviation with particular emphasis towards the chosen area of their thesis. The research thesis will examine an area of research significance as approved by the Head of Department.

Entry Requirements

Credit (WAM 65) plus average in BAv

Application Process

Complete Honours Enrolment form available from School of Aviation

Components (assessable items) of the Honours Program

  1. Tutorial classes (ongoing)
  2. Preliminary introduction and literature review (approximately mid-year 20%)
  3. Presentation 1 (approximately mid-year 5%)
  4. Presentation 2 (approximately end of year 10%)
  5. Thesis (end of year 65%)

Examination Procedure

All assessable items, excluding components 1 and 2 are marked by at least three academics.

Final Grade

Based on performance across all assessable items.

Range of Grades

  • Honours Class I (>85%)
  • Honours Class II Division I (75% to 84%)
  • Honours Class II Division II (65% to 74%)
  • Honours Class III (50% to 64%)
  • Fail (<49%)

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"16 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA4003 - Aviation Honours - Full Time","description":"

This course aims to help students achieve, through research, a deep understanding of a specific aspect of aviation, while developing a range of skills that are highly valued in industry. Students conduct research on a topic selected by them in consultation with their supervisor, and submit research thesis. A series of workshops supports students’ development of research skills. Attendance of School colloquia and presentations builds students’ knowledge of academic and industry developments within aviation.


Entry Requirements Credit-plus (i.e. WAM 65+) average in BAv


Application Process Application for entry into the Aviation Honours Program is made via the Science Faculty (https://www.science.unsw.edu.au/honours-apply) after obtaining agreement of a research supervisor (see https://www.aviation.unsw.edu.au/honours-aviation for relevant information.)


Components (assessable items) of the Honours Program


  1. Research skills workshops (Term 1; 0%)
  2. Research proposal (Week 6, first term of enrolment; 0%)
  3. Literature review (Week 5, second term of enrolment; 0%)
  4. Midway Presentation (Week 5, second term of enrolment; 0%)
  5. Final Presentation (Week 9, third term of enrolment;15%)
  6. Thesis (Week 10, third term of enrolment; 85%)

Examination Procedure All summative assessments (5 and 6) are marked by at least two academics.


Final Grade Based on performance across all summative assessments.


Range of Grades


  • Honours Class I (>85%)
  • Honours Class II Division I (75% to 84%)
  • Honours Class II Division II (65% to 74%)
  • Honours Class III (50% to 64%)
  • Fail (<49%)

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6ee7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"85","description":"

The written thesis should follow the format for a Masters or Ph.D. thesis, but will be shorter; the thesis should not exceed 20,000 words (not including appendices). Subject to agreement with the supervisor, this should normally include: Abstract, Introduction, Literature Review, Method, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, References, and Appendices (if required). Students should discuss the exact chapter structure with their supervisor. 

Each student will have their thesis critically assessed internally by at least two reviewers from the School of Aviation or TARS. Each member of the student's review committee will then independently read and assess the final thesis without consultation with each other. The following steps are followed for grading the thesis: 

  1. Thesis submitted and assessed by the two examiners. Examiners do not award a raw mark yet.
  2. Thesis defence conprising of the student, two examiners, Honours convenor and supervisor is held. The examiners have the opportunity to ask clarifying questions to the student.  
  3. Marks awarded by examiners.  
  4. If the two marks are greater than 5 marks apart, examiners, supervisor, and Honours coordinator meet and discuss to see if a consenus can be reached. If no resolution, a third examiner is called upon. The third examiner also has the opportunity to discuss the thesis (thesis defence) with the student. The average of the two closest marks will be used. 
  5. If two marks are within a range of 5 marks and in the same band (HD, DN, CR, PS, FL), final mark is the average of the two marks. If the marks are within the range of 5 marks, but between two bands, the supervisor can request a meeting with the examiners and Honours coordinator to clarify any issues in the examination reports. If marks remain within 5 marks, the average is taken as the final grade.  

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 10 of the student’s final term of enrolment.

After the submission of the thesis, the student will undergo an interview (Q&A) with the two thesis examiners, moderated by the Honours program coordinator. This interview is expected to be 20 to 30 minutes in duration. The examiners will inquire about the student’s research process, experience in conducting their research, decisions made that shaped their research, technical questions regarding methodology, and other research-related topics. The aim of the thesis defense is to allow the student to answer any questions the examiners may have when grading the thesis in an informal setting, and thus allow for a more accurate grading process.  

Application for an extension may be considered under very special circumstances. To be considered for an extension, please submit the special consideration form via UNSW Central along with supporting documents. Please note that submitting the special consideration form does not guarantee an extension. Late assessments, without a reason deemed satisfactory, will be penalised by a loss of 10% of the total possible marks for the due assessment per day.

Students are referred to the University’s rules on academic conduct, which are contained within the Student Handbook. Specifically, plagiarism is unacceptable and may lead to failure of the course, or in extreme cases exclusion from the University. Students are referred to the University's Student Handbook for full details on academic regulations.

Students are required to present their work-in-progress to an audience including lecturers, researchers and other research students. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work. The presentation must not be longer than 15 mins in duration. This is followed by 5 mins of Q & A.

The date/time/location of the presentation to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 4 of the student’s second term of enrolment. The Honours program coordinator will collate and provide written feedback from academic attendees within 1 week of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"22e7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6ee7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aae7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ae7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to present their research findings to an audience including lecturers and researchers (specific date to be provided by Program Coordinator no less than one month in advance) towards the end of their enrolment (normally in the final week of the final semester). The presentation must not be longer than 30 mins in duration. This is followed by 10 mins of questions and answers. Students will be assessed on the presentation and communication of their research output.  

Students are graded by the academics in the audience, and their final average mark is given to the student. This assessment task contruibtes to 15% of the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"22e7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"62e7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6ee7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aae7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"82e7e17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a research proposal to their supervisor and Honours program coordinator. The maximum word count is 1500 words. This will be marked by the students’ primary supervisor. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work.

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 4 of the student’s first term of enrolment. Submit to main supervisor and Honours program coordinator. Main supervisor’s role is to return with written feedback within 3 weeks of submission.

Students are required to submit a literature review of their research area to their supervisor and Honours program coordinator. The maximum word count is 3000 words. This will be marked by the student’s primary supervisor. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work.

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 3 of the student’s second term of enrolment. Submit to main supervisor and Honours program coordinator. Main supervisor’s role is to return with written feedback within 3 weeks of submission.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"8 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA4004 - Aviation Honours - Part Time","description":"

Undertaken over two years, this course aims to help students achieve, through research, a deep understanding of a specific aspect of aviation, while developing a range of skills that are highly valued in industry. Students conduct research on a topic selected by them in consultation with their supervisor, and submit research thesis. A series of workshops supports students’ development of research skills. Attendance of School colloquia and presentations builds students’ knowledge of academic and industry developments within aviation.


Entry Requirements Credit-plus (i.e. WAM 65+) average in BAv


Application Process Application for entry into the Aviation Honours Program is made via the Science Faculty (https://www.science.unsw.edu.au/honours-apply) after obtaining agreement of a research supervisor (see https://www.aviation.unsw.edu.au/honours-aviation for relevant information.)


Components (assessable items) of the Honours Program


  1. Research skills workshops (during first two terms; 0%)
  2. Research proposal (second term of enrolment; 0%)
  3. Literature review (fourth term of enrolment; 0%)
  4. Midway Presentation (fourth term of enrolment; 0%)
  5. Final Presentation (sixth term of enrolment;15%)
  6. Thesis (sixth term of enrolment; 85%)

Examination Procedure All summative assessments (5 and 6) are marked by at least two academics.


Final Grade Based on performance across all summative assessments.


Range of Grades


  • Honours Class I (>85%)
  • Honours Class II Division I (75% to 84%)
  • Honours Class II Division II (65% to 74%)
  • Honours Class III (50% to 64%)
  • Fail (<49%)

Students are required to present their work-in-progress to an audience including lecturers, researchers and other research students. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work. The presentation must not be longer than 15 mins in duration. This is followed by 5 mins of Q & A.

The date/time/location of the presentation to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 4 of the student’s fourth term of enrolment. The Honours program coordinator will collate and provide written feedback from academic attendees within 1 week of the presentation.

Students are required to submit a research proposal to their supervisor and Honours program coordinator. The maximum word count is 1500 words. This will be marked by the students’ primary supervisor. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work.

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 4 of the student’s second term of enrolment. Submit to main supervisor and Honours program coordinator. Main supervisor’s role is to return with written feedback within 3 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0ac665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bdc665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cac665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a5c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to present their research findings to an audience including lecturers and researchers (specific date to be provided by Program Coordinator no less than one month in advance) towards the end of their enrolment (normally in the final week of the final semester). The presentation must not be longer than 30 mins in duration. This is followed by 10 mins of questions and answers. Students will be assessed on the presentation and communication of their research output.  

Students are graded by the academics in the audience, and their final average mark is given to the student. This assessment task contruibtes to 15% of the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"35c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bdc665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c2c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adc665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

Students are required to submit a literature review of their research area to their supervisor and Honours program coordinator. The maximum word count is 3000 words. This will be marked by the student’s primary supervisor. This is a milestone/formative assessment that must be completed, though it has no weighting in the final Honours grade. The purpose of this task is to ensure that the student is working towards the expected schedule for all Honours students and to provide timely feedback on their work.

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 3 of the student’s fourth term of enrolment. Submit to main supervisor and Honours program coordinator. Main supervisor’s role is to return with written feedback within 3 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0ac665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"35c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71c665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bdc665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adc665b7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"85","description":"

The written thesis should follow the format for a Masters or Ph.D. thesis, but will be shorter; the thesis should not exceed 20,000 words (not including appendices). Subject to agreement with the supervisor, this should normally include: Abstract, Introduction, Literature Review, Method, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, References, and Appendices (if required). Students should discuss the exact chapter structure with their supervisor. 

Each student will have their thesis critically assessed internally by at least two reviewers from the School of Aviation or TARS. Each member of the student's review committee will then independently read and assess the final thesis without consultation with each other. The following steps are followed for grading the thesis: 

  1. Thesis submitted and assessed by the two examiners. Examiners do not award a raw mark yet.
  2. Thesis defence conprising of the student, two examiners, Honours convenor and supervisor is held. The examiners have the opportunity to ask clarifying questions to the student.  
  3. Marks awarded by examiners.  
  4. If the two marks are greater than 5 marks apart, examiners, supervisor, and Honours coordinator meet and discuss to see if a consenus can be reached. If no resolution, a third examiner is called upon. The third examiner also has the opportunity to discuss the thesis (thesis defence) with the student. The average of the two closest marks will be used. 
  5. If two marks are within a range of 5 marks and in the same band (HD, DN, CR, PS, FL), final mark is the average of the two marks. If the marks are within the range of 5 marks, but between two bands, the supervisor can request a meeting with the examiners and Honours coordinator to clarify any issues in the examination reports. If marks remain within 5 marks, the average is taken as the final grade.  

Due date to be announced by the Honours program coordinator, though this is typically in Week 10 of the student’s final term of enrolment.

After the submission of the thesis, the student will undergo an interview (Q&A) with the two thesis examiners, moderated by the Honours program coordinator. This interview is expected to be 20 to 30 minutes in duration. The examiners will inquire about the student’s research process, experience in conducting their research, decisions made that shaped their research, technical questions regarding methodology, and other research-related topics. The aim of the thesis defense is to allow the student to answer any questions the examiners may have when grading the thesis in an informal setting, and thus allow for a more accurate grading process.  

Application for an extension may be considered under very special circumstances. To be considered for an extension, please submit the special consideration form via UNSW Central along with supporting documents. Please note that submitting the special consideration form does not guarantee an extension. Late assessments, without a reason deemed satisfactory, will be penalised by a loss of 10% of the total possible marks for the due assessment per day.

Students are referred to the University’s rules on academic conduct, which are contained within the Student Handbook. Specifically, plagiarism is unacceptable and may lead to failure of the course, or in extreme cases exclusion from the University. Students are referred to the University's Student Handbook for full details on academic regulations.

This course aims to provide students with an overview of the regulatory structure of civil aviation in Australia. Aviation and the law share some basic similarities. Both the aviation and legal professions are highly specialised and each require an extensive degree of training before one can be classed as a “professional” within the respective disciplines. Although aviation professionals are highly trained technicians or managers it does not follow that such training has necessarily included training in the law and legal systems.


The fact that the aviation industry is a highly regulated and legislated sector provides an even greater reason why today’s aviation professional should be conversant with, and knowledgeable of, the law as it applies to the aviation industry. In most sections of the aviation industry there are no formal requirements for training in the law or legal systems. Of course there is a myriad of rules and regulations in aviation that must be known but that does not equate to training in statutory interpretation or the like.


Aviation professionals, like their legal counterparts, spend a long time undertaking formal, structured training. Then there follows years of practical, on-the-job training. In fact the training never really ends. Both professions require ongoing professional training. Because of the extensive time taken to “learn the profession” quite often people working in the aviation sector enter at an early age. It is not usually a career in which one ‘switches’ to later in their working life.

Students need to submit this assignment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

contentlets.description:
This course aims to provide students with an overview of the regulatory structure of civil aviation in Australia. Aviation and the law share some basic similarities. Both the aviation and legal professions are highly specialised and each require an extensive degree of training before one can be classed as a “professional” within the respective disciplines. Although aviation professionals are highly trained technicians or managers it does not follow that such training has necessarily included training in the law and legal systems.

The fact that the aviation industry is a highly regulated and legislated sector provides an even greater reason why today’s aviation professional should be conversant with, and knowledgeable of, the law as it applies to the aviation industry. In most sections of the aviation industry there are no formal requirements for training in the law or legal systems. Of course there is a myriad of rules and regulations in aviation that must be known but that does not equate to training in statutory interpretation or the like.

Aviation professionals, like their legal counterparts, spend a long time undertaking formal, structured training. Then there follows years of practical, on-the-job training. In fact the training never really ends. Both professions require ongoing professional training. Because of the extensive time taken to “learn the profession” quite often people working in the aviation sector enter at an early age. It is not usually a career in which one ‘switches’ to later in their working life.
contentlets.title: Law and Regulation in Aviation

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5003","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5003 - Aviation and Security","description":"

This course provides an insight to contemporary security issues, aviation security standards and recommended practices, aviation security principles and procedures. As the aviation industry grows so too does the potential for terrorist and criminal activities against the industry. Aviation has been and continues to be an attractive target for terrorist, including the recent attacks against airports and aircraft operators. This course  will also develop your skills to ask “What is the desired security outcome and can it be achieved in different ways”. Unless otherwise stated, the Australian examples used throughout the course are typical of international practice.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"10cb1d7bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Regulatory Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are research key piece of legislation impacting the security of the Aviation industry. Students are to inform the course convener of their topic by Week 3. This assessment is to be submitted via Moodle in Week 6. The assignment consists of 25  short-answer questions. In order to answer the questions, you will need access to the Internet and a number of pieces of legislation. This assignment will test your ability to answer specific questions by reference to specific legislation. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"10cbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5ccbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d4cb1d7bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40cbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This assignment is worth 50% of the course.  Students are required to provide answer with aviation security related examples taken from ICAO Annex 17, the Aviation Transport Security Act 2004 and/or the Aviation Transport Security Regulations 2005. When using examples from the legislation it is not necessary to quote the entire piece of regulation, just the applicable section(s) to support the argument/discussion, for example ATSR 4.67(2)(a). This task is available to students from the start of term. Students need to submit this assessment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission.

This is a formative quiz that is held in Week 3 to provide students with feedback on their progress. Students are given the opportunity to receive detailed feedback from the Course Convener during consultation hours or by appointment. This assessment item has no impact on the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"10cbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5ccbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"48cbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"CEO Briefing","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are to assume the role of an Airline Security Manager who has been requested to provide a (maximum) three-page submission to their CEO. Students will need to be concise with their submission containing:
• purpose of the submission (1 sentence maximum);
• the top three issues of this proposal – three headings (one for each issue) and dot points
explanations under each of the three headings;
• any options that should be considered or could be implemented and why; and
• recommendations, if any (1 paragraph).

The specific topic will be released via Moodle in Week 3. This assignment is due in Week 8. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5004 - Aviation Safety and Accident Prevention","description":"

This course aims to provide students with an overview of the paramount importance of safety and the systems that support safety in civil aviation in Australia and internationally. Aviation and the law share some basic similarities. Safety and accident prevention is an issue that encroaches upon practically every aspect of human endeavour; none more so than within the aviation industry. This course provides an overview of the safety system of civil aviation and of the cause of organisational accidents within such complex systems.



With advancements in accident investigation research techniques, legislative initiatives and international co-operation increasing, this area of the aviation industry has contributed enormously to the very high levels of aviation safety throughout the world. If all the conditions and factors causally related to aircraft accidents could be identified in advance then “zero accidents” may well be an achievable goal. Unfortunately, history and hindsight have repeatedly proven to be the only reliable sources of such information.

The purpose of this assignment  is to assess your understanding of the underlying principles of Aviation Safety and Accident Prevention and will concentrate on assessing your grasp of safety concepts, and the application of risk management principles to aviation scenarios and the aviation industry. Students need to submit this assignment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

This course is complementary to AVIA5009 Airline Corporate Management which is also provided in the MScTech (Aviation)/MAvMgmt program. The introductory module of this course provides a brief overview of the corporate side of airline management and its relationship with the following modules.


Airline operations are defined as the functional areas which are directly associated with the operations of the aircraft and in the provision of operational support services. There is much overlap between the management of “corporate” and “operational” aspects of an airline. This occurs mainly in the planning processes such as fleet planning, schedule planning, and strategic planning (including business plans and annual budgets). These important processes will be covered in this course for the functional areas that play major roles in the airline.


Engineering and maintenance, airline airport operations, crew resource provision and inflight service functions are specifically covered in some detail. As well as those important functional areas, other airline processes are covered which play important roles in the operations. These include emergency planning, operations control, and punctuality management.


The more recent interest in outsourcing in airline management is looked at as airlines pursue the reduction in costs and head towards the “virtual” airline. There is a module on environmental matters in the airline and also a chapter on freight. Perhaps the latter is a little misplaced but those of you who do both the courses on Airline management should have some exposure to the freight part of the airline.


General management techniques apply to many of these functional areas. Planning, budgeting, staff and equipment rostering, and disruption management are generic but in this course are discussed from the airline’s view. The management of aircraft, crew (both technical and cabin service crew), and inflight service functions are complex, especially the impact each has on the other. This may not be unique but certainly requires some knowledge of the history of the industry. The impact of outsourcing of services has put the traditional approaches under the microscope, and with varied results.

Assignment 3 consists of short-answer questions and two essay questions. This assessment item constitutes 35% of the final grade. Students need to submit this assignment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a5d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"665d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a25d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e25d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ee5d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e5d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 2500 word report on one of the following 2 topics: 

1. Discuss airline punctuality from both the airline and passenger perspective. How do airlines manage their operations to achieve on-time operations (OTP)? Consider whether airline OTP in Australia is at a satisfactory level for either airlines or for passengers? How does OTP in Australia compare with USA or Europe? What impact does consumer compensation for delays have on airline performance? You will find OTP stats reported by various agencies in each region; or
2. Discuss aircraft maintenance and how it has changed with advancements in technology. Consider an airline evaluating whether to purchase new aircraft or whether to continue operating its older aircraft fleet. How does aircraft maintenance affect this decision, and what are the impacts on the airline’s operational performance, aircraft utilisation, customer satisfaction and financial results?

This assignment constitutes 30% of the final grade. Assignment 1 is to be submitted via Moodle (Turnitin submission box) in Week 4. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a5d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"665d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a25d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"565d9d7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 2500 word report on one of the following 3 topics: 

1. High profile disruptions have happened recently with crew shortages at Ryanair and American Airlines. Discuss the ways in which airlines can minimise their crew costs. Give examples of crew management systems and their role in ensuring the airline has enough (but not too many) crew to operate its services. Look at the problem from the day to day to the long term and explain why the two time periods need to be related. Your reading and references should extend beyond the course notes. Use the library databases to find an article or two that can inform your assignment; or 

2. Managing the impacts on the environment is now a key issue for most industries including the aviation industry. Airline Operations Managers have obligations to meet increasing legislative compliance requirements. Outline the areas of concern that Airline Operating Managers need to be aware of and consider the actions the industry must take to be a responsible environmental citizen. You may wish to consider a specific area such as noise, fuel conservation, fleet re-equipment as the core theme of your paper; or

3. You have been asked to prepare a report on establishing a new low cost airline in Australia or Southeast Asia. In your report you will describe the functions to be established within the new airline and the functions to be outsourced. You will explain how financial, operational, regulatory, marketing and any other considerations affect your decisions. You may use examples from different airlines that
you are familiar with to illustrate your discussion.

This assignment constitutes 35% of the final grade. Assignment 2 is to be submitted via Moodle (Turnitin submission box) in Week 8. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students within 2 weeks of submission.

contentlets.description:
This course is complementary to AVIA5009 Airline Corporate Management which is also provided in the MScTech (Aviation)/MAvMgmt program. The introductory module of this course provides a brief overview of the corporate side of airline management and its relationship with the following modules.

Airline operations are defined as the functional areas which are directly associated with the operations of the aircraft and in the provision of operational support services. There is much overlap between the management of “corporate” and “operational” aspects of an airline. This occurs mainly in the planning processes such as fleet planning, schedule planning, and strategic planning (including business plans and annual budgets). These important processes will be covered in this course for the functional areas that play major roles in the airline.

Engineering and maintenance, airline airport operations, crew resource provision and inflight service functions are specifically covered in some detail. As well as those important functional areas, other airline processes are covered which play important roles in the operations. These include emergency planning, operations control, and punctuality management.

The more recent interest in outsourcing in airline management is looked at as airlines pursue the reduction in costs and head towards the “virtual” airline. There is a module on environmental matters in the airline and also a chapter on freight. Perhaps the latter is a little misplaced but those of you who do both the courses on Airline management should have some exposure to the freight part of the airline.

General management techniques apply to many of these functional areas. Planning, budgeting, staff and equipment rostering, and disruption management are generic but in this course are discussed from the airline’s view. The management of aircraft, crew (both technical and cabin service crew), and inflight service functions are complex, especially the impact each has on the other. This may not be unique but certainly requires some knowledge of the history of the industry. The impact of outsourcing of services has put the traditional approaches under the microscope, and with varied results.
contentlets.title: Airline Operational Management

The second assignment of 2500 words is due in Week 10. This assignment is worth 30% of the final grade. It again requires the student to adopt the role of an airport planning consultant, this time to prepare a report which identifies the likely impacts of a development proposal being considered by the airport owner on a site adjacent to the airport. Details, including the assignment question, will be released in Week 5. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

This assessment, which will take place during the exam week, will take the form of an end of course assessment based on course work. It will be posted on Moodle by UNSW at the beginning of the exam week. It is to be submitted electronically no later than date nominated by UNSW. The assignment consists of short-answer and multiple choice questions. All topics covered throughout the term will be assessed. Students will be given the opportunity receive feedback after the assignments have been graded. The final assessment is worth 50% of the final grade.

contentlets.description: Airport Planning includes the following: town planning aspects, access, obstacles, growth, longer term issues of noise and other environmental issues, longer term political issues and ownership issues as airports become privatised. Also included are topics covering the process of privatisation and investment evaluation, community benefits, airport master plans, forecasting aircraft movements and passenger and freight flows, terminal planning issues, runway and taxiway planning. Note: Distance Education mode only
contentlets.title: Airport Planning

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5007 - Airport Operations Management","description":"

This course covers day to day operational issues such as managing annual budgets, fees (landing, passenger, shops, car parking, etc.) determination methods, emergency planning in all aspects, relationships with airlines, short term political issues management, slot management-peak time issues, managing concessions and other airport business opportunities, aircraft parking control, relationship with other industry bodies and general administrative tasks at airports such as roads, signs, flight information, electricity and water. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e8d0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Early Assessment Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

This is a formative assessment item. In this course students will be provided with a set of 10-12 multiple choice questions at the beginning of the term. These will cover the first 3 weeks of course materials. Students should complete these questions with all serious intent one week prior to the Census Date. The Course facilitator will provide the correct answers prior to census date, and explanations for each.

This will provide students with formative feedback as to whether they have covered the key issues prior to census date. The marks will not be used as a summative contribution to the final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4d0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"00d0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment requires the student to adopt the role of airport operations manager of a regional airport. Research Assignment 2 has a maximum word limit of 2000 words, constitutes 25% of the final grade, and will be due in Week 9. The assignment will be released in Week 5 of the term. It requires the student, in the role of the airport operations manager, to prepare a project induction for a works contractor who has been engaged to carry out reconstruction of a critical section of the main apron. Marks for this assignment and detailed feedback will be posted on Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

The assignment relates to all five learning outcomes. The assignment must be submitted by lodgement through Moodle. Submission should be confirmed by email to the facilitator. Any application for an extension of time must be made in writing prior to the due date. Late assignments, without a reason deemed satisfactory by the facilitator, may be penalised by a loss of 10% of the total possible marks for the assignment per working day. Overly long assignments may also be penalised.

This assessment will comprise of multiple choice questions and short answer (short essay-style) questions. This assessment item is worth 50% of the final grade. Students need to submit this assignment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.
