This assignment requires the student to adopt the role of airport operations manager of a regional airport. Research Assignment 1 has a maximum word limit of 2000 words, constitutes 25% of the final grade, and will be due in Week 5. The assignment will be released in Week 2 of the term. It requires the student, in the role of airport operations manager, to prepare:  

  • an action plan outlining proposed responses to adverse findings about the existing state of airside operations and facilities; and
  • an implementation plan.

Marks for this assignment and detailed feedback will be posted on Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. The assignment relates to all five learning outcomes. The assignment must be submitted by lodgement through Moodle. Submission should be confirmed by email to the facilitator. Any application for an extension of time must be made in writing prior to the due date. Late assignments, without a reason deemed satisfactory by the facilitator, may be penalised by a loss of 10% of the total possible marks for the assignment per working day. Overly long assignments may also be penalised.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5008","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5008 - Air Traffic Management","description":"

This course aims to provide a variety of reference material to enable students with limited aviation experience to develop an understanding of Air Traffic Management (ATM) practises and issues, while at the same remaining interesting and relevant for those students with greater experience.  Because of the spread of student aviation experience, a great deal of background reading material is provided as the course aims to be interesting, challenging and equally enjoyable for all. By obtaining a full understanding of the ATM dimension, a holistic view on the aviation industry and the dependencies of the different stakeholders will be enabled. Students will obtain an understanding of the global ATM system, which has also been termed the ‘world’s most complex socio-technological system’. Assessments are based on real world or simulated real world situations and allow students to demonstrate their understanding of Air Traffic management issues. Student assessment is designed to reflect the learning outcomes, and meaningful and timely feedback will be provided on coursework. Application of the learned concepts in real-time scenarios and creativity in finding ways of solving problems will be awarded.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c9fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Early Assessment Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

This is a formative quiz that is held in Week 3 to provide students with feedback on their progress. Students are given the opportunity to receive detailed feedback from the Course Convener during consultation hours or by appointment. This assessment item has no impact on the final grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"70fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"20fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task will be released during the exam period. Students will have 1 week to complete this assessment item. Submission is via Turnitin in Moodle. It constitutes 50% of the final grade. The examiner is looking for “interesting” and “innovative” answers and not a ‘model answer’ copied from the text. Answers should wherever possible show an understanding of the interconnection between concepts theoretically explained in the course and the ‘real-life’ challenges they face. Students will be given the opportunity to receive feedback from the Course Convener. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"34fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"38fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"70fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"74fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"81fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bcfce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"cdfce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f4fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f8fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"28fce5b7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 1 will be released in week 2. Its is to be submitted by the end of Week 6. This assignment constitutes 20% of the final grade. Studens will choose between an essay question on 'Automated Technology in Aviation' and 'Human factors and Aviation Safety'. All arguments should be support with data and statistics. The word limit is 1200 words. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided by the course conveneor via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

Assignment 2 will be released in week 5. Its is to be submitted by the end of Week 10. This assignment constitutes 30% of the final grade. The word limit is 1200 words. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided by the course conveneor via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

contentlets.description: This course aims to provide a variety of reference material to enable students with limited aviation experience to develop an understanding of Air Traffic Management (ATM) practises and issues, while at the same remaining interesting and relevant for those students with greater experience.  Because of the spread of student aviation experience, a great deal of background reading material is provided as the course aims to be interesting, challenging and equally enjoyable for all. By obtaining a full understanding of the ATM dimension, a holistic view on the aviation industry and the dependencies of the different stakeholders will be enabled. Students will obtain an understanding of the global ATM system, which has also been termed the ‘world’s most complex socio-technological system’. Assessments are based on real world or simulated real world situations and allow students to demonstrate their understanding of Air Traffic management issues. Student assessment is designed to reflect the learning outcomes, and meaningful and timely feedback will be provided on coursework. Application of the learned concepts in real-time scenarios and creativity in finding ways of solving problems will be awarded.
contentlets.title: Air Traffic Management

Note: Distance Education mode only","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"469c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 800-1000 word report worth 20% of the final grade. It is to be submitted via Moodle in Week 5. The topic is as follows: 

Analyse the schedule and capacity data for the market between Australia (at a city pair level) and Indonesia for at least the past 5 years. What are the trends? Is there evidence of volatility in the market?  What is likely to happen in this market in the coming 2 years?

This requires critical thinking, research, and analysis. Conjecture and unsupported opinion will result in poor marks. You are expected to make use of the University’s online library resources and to use APA/Harvard style referencing - e.g. (Douglas, 2016) – in your paper. You may choose to include tables or charts in your paper to clarify and present your analysis, but these do don replace good written argument. The Australian Government publishes extensive aviation statistics. Access the BITRE database and download the necessary files from the Aviation section. https://bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/index.aspx

Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to studentd within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"399c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"759c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"829c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce9c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"699c5dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 1600-2000 word report worth 40% of the final grade. It is to be submitted at the end of Week 9 in Moodle. The topic is as follows: 

Unit costs are impacted by aircraft type, configuration, and sector length. Using the cost formula identified in the Adler and Swan paper undertake a study that considers the following variables, and analyses the relative cost structures. How much impact does configuration have? What is the ratio of space between cabin classes? Note that the KLM E175 and the BA A320 are short-haul services with standard economy seats fitted to the entire aircraft. How does this impact unit cost and customer comfort?

  1. Passenger connection between Tokyo (NRT/HND) and Dublin (DUB).
  2. Aircraft are JL B777-300ER 8F/49C/40W/147Y, EK B777-300ER 42C 0W 385Y, KL B777-300ER 34C 40W 354Y premium economy is only extended legroom, KL E175 20C/8W/60Y C is also economy seats (W class overwing exit rows), BA A320 24C 0W 132 Y (middle seat blocked in C – variable cabin)
  3. Schedule options are HND-LHR-DUB on Japan Airlines (JL) and British Airways (BA), NRT-DXB-DUB on Emirates (EK), NRT-AMS-DUB on KLM (KL)

The great circle distances for the schedules can be obtained from www.gcmap.com or a similar source. Please work in km not miles. This assignment requires interpretation, analysis, and the integration of data from multiple sources. Simply reporting or summarising available data will NOT gain marks. This assignment requires analysis, synthesis, and the development of informed view.

Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students within 2 weeks of submission.

This assessment constitutes 40% of the final grade.The assignment contains two parts. The first is made up of short answer questions touching on recent airline events. The second part will require completion of a route economics study using data provided. Students need to submit Assignment 3 in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

contentlets.description: Airline Corporate Management includes organisational structures, business planning and budgeting, financial analysis, supply and demand analysis, economics, forecasting, commercial agreements liaisons, scheduling planning and fleet planning. This course provides an insight into the complex and interwoven nature of the airline business and gives a picture of the prime drivers, which differentiate airlines. This course is complementary to course AVIA5005 Airline Operational Management. Note: Distance Education mode only
contentlets.title: Airline Corporate Management

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5015","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5015 - Safety Management Systems","description":"

This course is intended to provide the student with an understanding of the principles that apply to an aviation safety system and an understanding the complex interaction between individuals and organisations to which those principles apply.


Modern jet transport systems now enable people to travel vast distances at high-speed, within a highly hazardous environment, yet paradoxically with minimal risk. A significant reason for this is the development of Safety Management Systems (SMS). Successful completion of this module is expected to equip the student with the theoretical knowledge of the requirements of a SMS as described by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the Civil Aviation Authority (Australia) (CASA).


Another aspect of a modern SMS is the investigation of aircraft accidents and incidents. In the past, engineering solutions led to significant improvements. However, over time, such investigations revealed that accidents and incidents were often not the product of a single cause, but were more likely to have resulted from a combination of factors. Many of those factors were linked to the ways in which the behaviour of individuals was adversely influenced by task related and systemic conditions, which has led to a breakdown in safety. With the growing complexity of aviation passenger transport operations it has therefore become increasingly necessary to look beyond the actions of individuals in order to understand those system based, error-producing conditions that adversely influence their actions.


Safety management systems are now increasingly used by organisations to ensure that all aspects of their operations that could affect safety have been adequately addressed. Typically, such systems provide for:


  • The establishment of organisational safety objectives and policy;
  • A commitment by senior management to safety;
  • The promotion of a positive safety culture;
  • The identification of safety hazards and the management of risk;
  • The means of measuring and maintaining organisational safety health:
  • Procedures for the rectification of safety deficiencies; and
  • Emergency response procedures.

Assignment 1 includes all materials covered in Units 1 to 5, inclusive. It is a 2000-word essay and will be released in Week 2 via Moodle. A 10% tolerance for the expected word length is permitted. This assessment item constitutes 40% of the final grade. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

Students are required to complete BOTH Assignment 1 and the Assignment 2 in order to complete the requirements of this course.

Unless otherwise specified, the following criteria will be applied in assessing your written work:
• evidence of understanding of the concepts, theories and ideas developed in the course;
• ability to apply those concepts to situations from your own experience;
• capability to structure an assignment logically and limit it to the length required;
• the degree to which the material submitted for assessment addresses the specified or
negotiated assignment requirements; and
• the proper use of grammar, spelling, style, and academic referencing, together with an
appropriate mix of research and original thought.
The examiner is looking for interesting and innovative answers and not a ‘model answer’ derived from the
text. Answers that consist of a succession of “quotes” will not attract high marks.

Students will be asked to complete a mixture of short answer and essay questions. The assignment constitutes 60% of the final grade. The assessor is looking for thoughtful, interesting and innovative answers and not the repetition of the course notes. The purpose of these assignments is to assess: (1) your knowledge and understanding of the course material, (2) your ability to apply that understanding, and (3) your ability to critically assess current safety systems and suggest how these systems might be developed. Students need to submit Assignment 2 in the first week of Exam Period. . Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

Students are required to complete BOTH Assignment 1 and Assignment 2 in order to complete the requirements of this course.

Unless otherwise specified, the following criteria will be applied in assessing your written work:
• evidence of understanding of the concepts, theories and ideas developed in the course;
• ability to apply those concepts to situations from your own experience;
• capability to structure an assignment logically and limit it to the length required;
• the degree to which the material submitted for assessment addresses the specified or
negotiated assignment requirements; and
• the proper use of grammar, spelling, style, and academic referencing, together with an
appropriate mix of research and original thought.
The assessor is looking for interesting and innovative answers and not a ‘model answer’ derived from the text. Answers that consist of a succession of “quotes” will not attract high marks.

Safety","description":"

This course focusses on the application of human factors in the context of transportation, and particularly transportation safety. It will consider the role that human factors play in normal operations, as well as in the tragedies that garner media attention. Most of the concepts discussed are applicable across transportation modes, and examples will be drawn from aviation, rail, maritime, road, and even space, transportation. The primary focus of the course is on commercial, rather than private, transportation.


The course first presents some fundamentals of human factors and human performance. It then examines human factors issues for different elements of transportation systems: design, operation, maintenance and management.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"60a9e97fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task comprises 2 sub-tasks, as below.

a) Bibliography: Students provide citations and brief summaries of 3 news stories and a draft review of one news story. (500 words, 0%, due in Week 4). This sub-task aims to provide early feedback prior to the Census date to help students ascertain their commitment to the courseand and formative feedback to make sure students are on the right track for success with the final submission of the Critical Review assignment.

b) Final submission: Students review 3 news stories concerning human factors in transportation in relation to human performance concepts from Weeks 1 to 5. (1500 words, 40%, due in Week 7).

Grading will be based on how well students:

  • demonstrate understanding of the theories, concepts and information developed in the course;
  • apply these theories, concepts and information to situations reported in the media and from their own experience;
  • address the specified requirements of the assignment;
  • present the assignment in a logical/suggested structure and within the word/page limit

Feedback will consist of the completed marking rubric and written comments on the returned assignment. Feedback aims to provide information to students at three basic levels:

  1. Where am I going? (the goals) - Feed Up - how performance relates to the broad goals of the course;
  2. How am I going? - Feed Back - how successful at addressing the task and its criteria;
  3. Where to next? - Feed Forward - how could the response to the task / performance be improved.

This assessment task comprises 2 sub-tasks, as below.

a) Design selection (0%, Week 8): Students submit their selection of 3 designs (one from each group of Tools, Tasks and jobs, and Safety management procedures, covering a minimum of 2 transportation modes of aviation, road and rail) for approval and formative feedback.

b) Final submission (2500 words, 60%, Final week in the exam period- week 12): Students analyse the 3 selected designs and evaluate their strengths and weaknesses with reference to human factors theory and research and offer recommendations for safety enhancement.

Grading will be based on how well students:

  • demonstrate understanding of the theories, concepts and information developed in the course;
  • apply these theories, concepts and information to situations from their own experience;
  • address the specified requirements of the assignment;
  • present the report in a logical/suggested structure and within the word/page limit.

Feedback will consist of the completed marking rubric and written feedback on the returned report. Feedback aims to provide information to students at three basic levels:

  3. Where to next? - Feed Forward - how could the response to the task / performance be improved.

contentlets.description:
This course focusses on the application of human factors in the context of transportation, and particularly transportation safety. It will consider the role that human factors play in normal operations, as well as in the tragedies that garner media attention. Most of the concepts discussed are applicable across transportation modes, and examples will be drawn from aviation, rail, maritime, road, and even space, transportation. The primary focus of the course is on commercial, rather than private, transportation.

The course first presents some fundamentals of human factors and human performance. It then examines human factors issues for different elements of transportation systems: design, operation, maintenance and management.
contentlets.title: Human Factors in Transportation Safety

Aviation Human Factors is a multi-disciplinary subject area that influences all aspects of the aviation environment from ramp to hangar and from security screening to the flight deck. Theoretical and applied human factors perspectives will be explored on the course. Topics include modern precepts of human error, aspects of physical and cognitive performance such as situation awareness, nontechnical skills, the human factors of unmanned aerial systems, the strengths and limitations of automation, accident investigation, and human performance aspects of maintenance, air traffic management and flight operations. The course has particular relevance for those involved in management, delving into organisational culture and the organisational influences on safety.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bebfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a96190e","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short Answer Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This will require responses to five questions out of a choice of about 12 questions. Each response will require about 250 word answers (not including references) for a total word length of about 1,500. The questions will be released on Moodle in a separate document. It is expected that responses will reference the academic literature to substantiate your argument/analysis. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission. Submission will be in Week 5. The assessment task will be released to students in Week 3. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"62bf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aebf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fabfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52bf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

A choice of at least six essay topics will be provided. You are to choose just one topic. A submission of 2,000 words (plus or minus 10%; excluding references and any annexes you may wish to provide) is the requirement. Essays above the 2,200 word limit are likely to be returned for reworking. The essay must be written as a proper academic paper and will be marked in accordance with normal
academic conventions/standards. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission. Submission will be in Week 9. The essay topics will be released to students in Week 5. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3abfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"62bf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"76bfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aebf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b2bfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fabfde2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aabf9e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

There will be a choice of questions to answer and the questions will be made available at the commencement of the examination/final assessment period. This is a tke-home exam and students will have 1 week to submit their answers.  The purpose of the exam is to test your understanding of aviation human factors and your ability to apply this understanding to the operational environment.

The exam will not be simply a test of factual knowledge. You will be able to access references etc., but the essay questions may not be the sort of questions that you can 'find' the answer to on the internet. To do well in the examination, you are encouraged to absorb the essential readings of the course and explore some of the topic areas further through your own research. The exam questions will assume a thorough understanding of the course manual and essential readings. Questions may relate to several modules, and generally test for understanding of concepts rather than facts. Students who have engaged in reading of the human factors literature beyond the
course notes may be at an advantage for the exam.

The format of the exam is a compbination of short-answer and essay questions. Students will be given the opportunity after the exam to view their exam paper and receive detailed feedback by appointment with the course convener after the exams have been graded.

The project involves an original investigation to determine answers to questions that are relevant and useful to development in some areas of aviation. The start of research project therefore is the formulation of a solid main research question. In order to be able to answer the main research question, sub research questions can be formulated. For example: a main research question can be “What is the impact of long distance low cost carriers on the development of the network of full service carriers”. Subresearch questions can be “What is the definition of a long distance low cost carrier”, “What carriers offer a long distance low cost service”, “What is the typical business model of a long distance low cost carrier” etc. In the research project finding answers to these sub-research questions allows the student to answer the main research question. The project should be significant and of substantive depth (so as to be equivalent to 1/8 of a year's academic work, and typically that is required for each of the postgraduate course work courses, i.e. 100 hours). It may involve researching aspects of the student's employment organizational functions, or some other area of aviation interest.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5031ae2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96191d","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

The research porposal does not contribute to the final grade and is a formative assessment item. It is to be submitted via Moodle at the end of Week 3. Aviation’s AVIA5020 Course Facilitator will review the proposed research topic and may assign a supervisor within the School of Aviation who is familiar with the chosen area, or may be the supervisor. The appointed supervisor will provide comments on the proposed research topic, and approve/disapprove the project and research topic, preferably before the census date. The Research Proposal should be structured as follows:
1) COVER PAGE
2) AIMS
3) BACKGROUND
4) METHODOLOGY
5) REFERENCES

Failure to submit the research topic proposal on time may result in getting a response later than the census date. Please note that submission of a research project report without having the explicit written approval of the research topic will lead to a course failure.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c31ae2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d831ae2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c31ae2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"100","description":"

The final Research Report should be a complete description of the project aims, motivation, methods, and conclusions, and be self contained and written in a professional manner. A research paper structure is often a good way to present your work. A good example of research paper structure appears in the journal “Safety Science”, which is an Elsevier Publication, available through the UNSW e-library. References within the text are indicated by author(s) name and date of publication, and a complete list of all references appears in alphabetical order at the end of the paper. References do NOT appear as footnotes in this journal. This report constitutes 100% of the final grade. 

By week 4 of the semester the student may submit a summary of progress describing the progress made via e-mail to the supervisor. The format of this progress report is open, but should include a description of how you are proceeding with your plan, and if anything in your plan needs to be changed.


By week 8 of the semester the student must submit a preliminary version of the Research Report via e-mail to the supervisor. This may be an unformatted version of the report. It is however important to submit this preliminary version in order to allow the supervisor to provide feedback required for the completion of the final Research Report. Failure to submit a preliminary version of the Research Report may lead to course failure.

Official submission date for the final report is at the end of Week 10. The submission of the final report must be done via the UNSW Moodle AVIA5020 website. Failure to submit a final report by the due date will result in a course failure, unless an extension has been granted prior to the due date. If students are unable to submit their final report by the due date, they must contact the course facilitator. Marks and deatiled feedback/comments will be provided within 3 weeks of submission. 

The Report should typically include:


1) COVER PAGE
2) ABSTRACT
3) INTRODUCTION
4) AIMS
5) METHODOLOGY
6) RESULTS
7) CONCLUSIONS
8) REFERENCES
 

The supervisor will mark the Research Report. The marks will be reviewed by the Course Facilitator (Prof Lodewijks). The School of Aviation will approve the final mark.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5022","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5022 - Aircraft Accident Investigation Techniques","description":"

This 6 UoC course is intended to provide you with a general understanding of the processes of aircraft incident and accident investigation, in order that you might better understand the role of air safety investigation in the wider aviation context. The investigation of aircraft incidents and accidents is now recognized as an essential component of an effective safety management system. By its very nature, an aircraft accident represents some form of failure of the aviation safety system. In many cases, valuable insights into the safety health of an organization can be gained by the effective use of proven incident / accident investigation techniques. Such investigations are necessarily ‘reactive’ but do provide a valuable ‘snapshot’ of how flight operations, maintenance practices and general company management was actually being conducted at the time of the event. When combined with a ‘proactive’ incident reporting and investigation program (now components of a Safety Management System) the often hidden factors that adversely influence the actions of operational personnel can be revealed.


The investigation techniques examined in this course are directed solely to the objective of accident prevention. The apportioning of blame or the determination of liability is not part of this process. In many cases, aircraft accident investigations are commenced in chaotic, stressful, and sometimes physically challenging situations. Such circumstances can place significant demands on investigators. It is at those very times that a thorough understanding of the process of investigation is essential to ensure that all elements are properly addressed during that initial phase. Once the dust has settled the investigation enters a more ordered phase, where the likely course of the investigation becomes clearer, leading in time to the identification of significant factors and deficiencies, ultimately resulting in safety actions or recommendations designed to prevent a recurrence of the same type of event.

This assignment is worth 40% of the final grade. Assignment 1 consists of the End of Unit exercises for Units 1 to 5, inclusive. The expected word length is 2000 words (+/- 10%). The details of assignment 1 will be released in Moodle in Week 2. It is to be submitted via Moodle in Week 6. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13bbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5fbbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"abbbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"afbbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0bbbd97bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Assignment 2 covers all materials taught throughout term. The format of the assignment consists of short-answer questions and two essay questions. The assessor is looking for thoughtful, interesting and innovative answers and not the repetition of the course notes. The purpose of these assignments is to test: (1) knowledge and understanding of the course material, (2) ability to apply that understanding, and (3) ability to critically assess current safety systems and suggest how these systems might be developed. Students need to submit this assessment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

contentlets.description:
This 6 UoC course is intended to provide you with a general understanding of the processes of aircraft incident and accident investigation, in order that you might better understand the role of air safety investigation in the wider aviation context. The investigation of aircraft incidents and accidents is now recognized as an essential component of an effective safety management system. By its very nature, an aircraft accident represents some form of failure of the aviation safety system. In many cases, valuable insights into the safety health of an organization can be gained by the effective use of proven incident / accident investigation techniques. Such investigations are necessarily ‘reactive’ but do provide a valuable ‘snapshot’ of how flight operations, maintenance practices and general company management was actually being conducted at the time of the event. When combined with a ‘proactive’ incident reporting and investigation program (now components of a Safety Management System) the often hidden factors that adversely influence the actions of operational personnel can be revealed.

The investigation techniques examined in this course are directed solely to the objective of accident prevention. The apportioning of blame or the determination of liability is not part of this process. In many cases, aircraft accident investigations are commenced in chaotic, stressful, and sometimes physically challenging situations. Such circumstances can place significant demands on investigators. It is at those very times that a thorough understanding of the process of investigation is essential to ensure that all elements are properly addressed during that initial phase. Once the dust has settled the investigation enters a more ordered phase, where the likely course of the investigation becomes clearer, leading in time to the identification of significant factors and deficiencies, ultimately resulting in safety actions or recommendations designed to prevent a recurrence of the same type of event.
contentlets.title: Aircraft Accident Investigation Techniques

Assignment 1 constitutes 40% of the final grade. In this assignment you are asked to take the concepts discussed in the context of advanced flight decks and apply them to an information processing environment of some complexity. The environment chosen should be one well understood by you and may be within the aviation industry or any other field. You are invited to demonstrate your understanding of these concepts through in their application in your chosen field. Maximum word count is 4000 words. Assignment 1 is due on Week 7 of Term. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission.

The final assignment is worth 60% of the total assessment. You will be given a week to prepare a position paper and submit the work through the UNSW Moodle website during the Exam Week. The assignment will set you a task that draws on the knowledge gained during the course to identify potential threats, mitigations and other issues facing an aviation organisation adapting to a changing level of technology. You are not expected to spend an inordinate length of time preparing your paper. Students will have the opportunity to  receive feedback from the convener.

contentlets.description: This course takes a holistic approach to analysing the factors involved in safe operation of advanced transport aircraft, beginning with a description of current accident statistics, and their analyses. The course includes an extensive description of advanced aircraft technology such as fly-by-wire, and the interfaces between aircraft and crew such as electronic cockpit displays, heads-up displays, cockpit controls, and automation. The course reviews human performance issues such as cognition, mental models, situational awareness and decision-making from the perspective of flight crew. It concludes with an overview of current world best proctices for flight crew and aviation organisations. The course is intended for professional flight crew, aviation managers, equipment manufacturers, researchers, regulators and interested parties who would benefit from a more complete knowledge of this complex area. Note: Distance Education mode only
contentlets.title: Flight Deck Operations for Advanced Transport-Aircraft

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5030","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5030 - Aviation, Tourism and Sustainable Development","description":"

The growing mobility and motility at national and international levels are having unprecedented sustainability implications for many regions and countries. Tourism is a broad term that includes wide ranging travel purpose such as business, leisure, pilgrimage, special events, and more, while air transport is a key travel mode through which these travels are realised and stimulated. Despite the obvious and accepted view that aviation and tourism are inter-related, aviation and tourism research and education have evolved in relative isolation from one another. This course aims to fill this gap by assisting students develop a broad understanding of one of the fastest growing sectors of an economy, so that students from both aviation and tourism sectors can take a coherent view of their research, analysis, management and policy impacts.


In this course students will develop the capacity to apply economic and geographic concepts and theories to understand air transport and tourism interactions in the context of sustainable development. In so doing, students will be introduced to issues in aeropolitics and tourism access, analytical methods to measure and quantify aviation's tourism impact, the economic geography of airline networks and route development. Select reading and case study materials area available to represent a balance of global and local issues.

This assignment covers the main topics introduced in Unit5-9. The emphasis is on the practical applications of core concepts introduced throughout the course. The assignment requires students consult a mix of multimedia sources and academic journals. Grading will be completed within 2 weeks of submission.

The final examination will be a take home paper and worth 35% of the total assessment. Students will have one week to complete the short-answer and essay-style examination. The purpose of the exam is to test student understanding of the concepts introduced in the course and the concepts’ value in explaining the broad spectrum of aviation-tourism issues in the context of sustainable development. In demonstrating student understanding, the use of original examples is encouraged. Students will be permitted to use their MScTech (Aviation) Manual, as well as any other reference materials.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5032","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5032 - Quantitative Analysis in Aviation Economics","description":"

This is an online course designed for post-graduate students focusing on the application of quantitative methods in the field of aviation. This course provides the student with a fundamental understanding of the quantitative skills and techniques applied in aviation economics, including a combination of specialised skills in modelling, understanding and forecasting air transport trends and drivers. This course implements an applied teaching approach, using seminal papers in the field as case studies to provide students with the ability to grasp and understand contemporary issues in aviation. Topics will be accompanied with short video presentations.

Students will receive their grades and feedback within 1 week if submission via Moodle. This assessment task will provide assess students' abilities to apply the topics learnt in the first 3 Units - sampling theory, probability theory, normal distribution and hypothesis testing.

In this course you will be provided with a set of 12 multiple choice questions at the beginning of semester. These will cover the first 3 weeks of course materials.  You should complete these questions with all serious intent one week prior to the Census Date. The Course facilitator will provide the correct answers prior to census date, and explanations for each question. contentlets.description: This is an online course designed for post-graduate students focusing on the application of quantitative methods in the field of aviation. This course provides the student with a fundamental understanding of the quantitative skills and techniques applied in aviation economics, including a combination of specialised skills in modelling, understanding and forecasting air transport trends and drivers. This course implements an applied teaching approach, using seminal papers in the field as case studies to provide students with the ability to grasp and understand contemporary issues in aviation. Topics will be accompanied with short video presentations.
contentlets.title: Quantitative Analysis in Aviation Economics

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5035","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5035 - Airport Economics, Management and Policy","description":"

In this global world, airports play a vital role enabling cities and regional and national economies to compete. The provision of airport infrastructure is costly and there usually is a limited number of sites in a given area suitable for airport development. Proposals to build new airports or to undertake major redevelopments at existing airports attract considerable public attention. A modern airport also is a complex economic and legal entity in which a variety of stakeholders are required to cooperate to deliver what is in principle a very simple product – the transfer of passengers and cargo between air and ground transport. It is not surprising to find that there are many courses on airport management and a wealth of published material on almost every aspect of airport development and operations.


This course blends elements of economics and management to explore key policy and strategic questions about airports. The aim is to equip participants, whether their interest be in airports, airlines, service provision, investment or regulation, to apply sound reasoning and knowledge to address these key questions. On conclusion of the course, participants will appreciate the economic and managerial challenges that will shape the future of financing, managing and regulating airports. Though AVIA5035 – Airport Economics, Management & Policy can be undertaken as a stand-alone component of the MScTech (Aviation)/MAvMgmt programme it complements other courses, notably: AVIA5006 – Airport Planning; and AVIA5007 – Airport Operations Management.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c00ddd3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Early Assessment Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

This is a formative assessment item. In this course you will be provided with a set of 12 multiple choice questions at the beginning of each semester. These will cover the first 3 weeks of course materials. You should complete these questions with all serious intent one week prior to the Census Date (31 March for S1 and 31 August for S2). The Course facilitator will provide the correct answers prior to census date, and explanations for each.

Marking yourself honestly therefore will provide you with formative feedback as to whether you have covered the key issues prior to census date. The marks will not be used as a summative contribution to your final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 2000-word report that is worth 25% of the final grade. It is to be submitted at the end of Week 5 via Moodle. Students will choose one from the following list of essay titles:

  1. Airports have to strike a balance between quality of service and the charges they must levy. Often, there are significantly diverging views between airlines, passengers and local interest groups on what levels of service should be provided, or at least there are widely differing values placed on the different types of service – the term “gold plating” often used in such discussions. Identify the issues that are at the heart of such disputes, how common are they and discuss possible methods of resolution.
  2. Discuss the application of benchmarking in an airport context, including consideration of the challenges of comparing one airport with another, and in particular airports in difference countries. What issues should be considered when using benchmarking as part of a policy processes. Illustrate your key points with examples wherever possible.
  3. The pricing principles adopted by the Australian Government, on the advice of the Productivity Commission, differ from those promulgated by ICAO. Identify the underlying policy principles of each approach and their strengths and weaknesses. Identify in what circumstances each is more likely to maximise economic efficiency.

Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"37fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 2000-word report that is worth 25% of the final grade. It is to be submitted at the end of Week 8 via Moodle. Students will choose one from the following list of essay titles:

  1. The notes for Unit 6 cite the Australian Productivity Commission (2011) thus: “in assessing the case for the economic regulation of airports services, it is necessary to arrive at a judgment about which services are amenable to the exercise of market power by airport operators.” Using examples to illustrate your arguments, assess which types of airport services are more likely to involve market power on the part of the airport operators and consider what are the incentives to exercise such market power. How do these differ between different types of airports is technology impacting of how airport might gain and use market power?
  2. Australia has one of the highest levels of private ownership of airports in the world and a “light handed” regulatory. Does such a framework maximise benefits to the community particularly from the perspective of ensuring adequate investment and competition in airline markets.
  3. It has become common place for airports to publish what are often referred to as “economic impact studies”. Provide examples of such publications and critically review the methods used and the conclusions reached. Comment on the claim that many such studies significantly over-state the impacts of projects or events, and assess the value such studies in enhancing the relationship between airports and their host communities.

Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"37fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

This assignment constitutes 50% of the final grade. The assignment will consist of two parts: Part A will comprise short answer questions drawn from any section of the course; and Part B will require students to answer two essay style questions.The purpose of the assignment is to assess student's understanding of the course material, and ability to apply that understanding to a given situation.

The marker is looking for thoughtful and innovative answers that display your depth of understanding of the course material. Answers that appear to consist of a succession of “quotes” will not attract high marks. Students need to submit this assignment in the first week of Exam Period. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided to students via Moodle within 2 weeks of submission. 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"37fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7ffc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bbfc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f7fc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"effc9d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/AVIA5035.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA5037","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA5037 - Airline Operations and Delay Management","description":"

This course is offered in T1 and focuses on: airline ground operations (including passenger facilitation and aircraft turnaround operations), delay data collection, delay data analysis, delay development modelling, airline networks and the emerging concept of robust airline scheduling. The rationale of this course is to provide students with practical airline operations knowledge, coupled with the use of mathmatical models in delay analysis, leading to the study of ways to improve the robustness of airline schedule in actual operations. Hence, some units of this course may contain mathematical models that require extra efforts in self-study. On-going assistance and virtual classroom discussion on Moodle will be organised. Basic statistical knowledge is ideal for this course. Students with airline operations experience may be able to grasp this course quickly; however, prior operations experience is not essential for studying this course.

A 'take-home' mid-term exam is designed to assess student performance and learning for the first half of the semester. This exam includes short essay questions and calculation questions that are designed to assess student knowledge of both understanding airline operational management principles and certain mathematical models that are used to solve industrial problems. The exam is designed in a stimulating style that motivates student learning and elevates learning outcomes.


Students will receive feedback on the scope,  depth and general quality of
their mid term exam within two weeks after the exam is graded.

In this Course we consider each of these major phases that together constitute airworthiness. These phases are grouped under two descriptive headings, referred to as Initial Airworthiness and Continuing Airworthiness. The focus is on the concepts, principles, regulations, organisational processes and systems that enable airworthiness to be initially attained and subsequently sustained throughout the aircraft’s life. In turn we then focus on the responsibilities and accountabilities of the managers and key personnel who make all this happen day-to-day, as these may well be the roles that graduates of this Course ultimately occupy


 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5b5ddd7fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Essay topic on Airworthiness Regulations and Requirements: to be issued in Week 3 and due in Week 5. Marks and detailed feedback will be provided by the Course Convener within 2 weeks of submission. Essay length of 1300-1500 words (excluding references and any appendices). This essay consititutes 30% of the final grade. 

Characteristics associated with competent essays are:

  • evidence of understanding of the concepts, principles, requirements and best practices considered in the Course;
  • comprehensive and appropriate coverage of relevant issues for the given topic, addressing the specified assignment requirements;
  • where appropriate, the incorporation of brief personal, professional experience to illustrate important issues;
  • ability to structure a logical presentation of information and argument concisely and accurately written within the stipulated length;
  • appropriate use of reference material, evidence of research and deliberations beyond the Course notes and appropriate and correct referencing (see below); and
  • appropriate acknowledgement of material, to avoid issues with respect to plagiarism.

These phases are grouped under two descriptive headings, referred to as Initial Airworthiness and Continuing Airworthiness. The focus is on the concepts, principles, regulations, organisational processes and systems that enable airworthiness to be initially attained and subsequently sustained throughout the aircraft’s life. In turn we then focus on the responsibilities and accountabilities of the managers and key personnel who make all this happen day-to-day, as these may well be the roles that graduates of this Course ultimately occupy
contentlets.title: Airworthiness for Transport Category Aircraft

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AVIA9101","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AVIA9101 - Safety Risk Management: Human Performance","description":"

The course provides an introduction to safety risk management with a focus on issues in human performance. Basic processes in risk management and safety are introduced, including the risk management framework, and concepts of injury and hazard control. Models for managing workplace safety are introduced as these underlie the management systems for other types of risk, and are a useful frame for a consideration of human factors in safety. Students will evaluate conceptual issues surrounding a range of hazards where human interaction with systems is paramount, and consider their measurement, monitoring, and risk management strategies. Commonly employed hazard control mechanisms, which are relevant to human performance will also be evaluated.

Safety Risk Management: Physical Hazards","description":"

This course examines the principles of safety risk management, focusing on physical hazards. Students will learn about methods of risk identification assessment and control applied to physical hazards including: manual handling, noise, electricity, chemical hazards, as well as learning about issues relating to major hazards and disasters. Students will be asked to apply risk management techniques to these hazards, and will have the opportunity to share and discuss their own experiences of managing risks. The course will also explore different theories of accident causation.
